Pot stickers to die for!  Honestly, I think my husband and I were the only non-Asian diners there, which should say something about the quality of the food.  The beef and broccoli was fab, and the portions are filling.  I rarely order wine at an Asian restaurant, but I did at Noodle Asia, and the house red was really good.  I was pleasantly surprised.  It is tucked behind the slot machines and there is generally a line to get in, but it moves quickly.  Great for lunch or dinner, and the price point is right on.

This is about as authentic as you can get for Hong Kong style noodles and rice dishes. Just take a look! Most of the customers are Asian; most of the wait staff is Asian and of course the 4 chefs/cooks are Asian.

Yes, it costs more since it is in the Venetian but by the time you get in a cab or drive to Chinatown, you have wasted precious time away from strip. 

I recommend any of the noodle or rice dishes - big dishes too. What is more impressive is the dim sum. They have it ready to steam and it comes out fresh. 

And the additional bonus - cleaner than those chinatown establishments.

Unfortunately I am one of those Asian that cannot live without noodles for more than 48 hours.

I go to Vegas via plane, it is a short flight from OC so very convenient.  But that means my noodle resources are limited in the strip hotels.  So I pretty much tried all the noodle restaurants on the strip, and I can only sum up with one word - #$%^&.  Yeah, most are that bad!  Overpriced, terrible attitude, small portion, terrible food.  The only exception is this one. They cannot compare to 626 or OC noodle shops but they do have the best quality on the strip.  More importantly, their staff are all very helpful and smiley.  The lady serving us took five minutes to explain most of their popular noodles, that was unheard of.  So even though this place is a little far from my hotel, I always make a point to go there.  Trust me, if you want noodle, and you are limited on the strip, then don't think, this is your only place. But if you have a car, then the options are wide open, think China Town....

Can't argue with 3am and i can get food  So great.

My recent staples are 
Spicy beef noodle soup 
Fried rice seafood. 
Stir fry string bean
Pan toasted noodle with mix seafood. Yum.

I ordered the Dan Dan noodles which I've never tried before. It was slightly sour? Not sure if that's supposed to be a thing. It wasn't for me, but after a night of drunk gambling, I must admit I ate the whole thing. The noodles were nice, not over cooked, just not a fan of the dish I suppose. We were seated fairly fast, and were in and out within 40 minutes.

Good old reliable noodle Asia. Late night snack when I'm craving Asian and grand luxe cafe do pretty terrible Asian food. 

I had the spicy wontons (red wontons) for entree, Singapore noodles and spicy beef noodle. Crispy chicken and spring rolls though they looked bad still tasted pretty good. All in all pretty good considering

You are at The Venetian Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas and it is after 2AM with very limited options to eat. Enter Noodle Asia. They are open till 3AM. One can have a full meal if desired. That is exactly what we did. We were seated immediately. The restaurant was busy for 2:15AM. 
I wanted to have the Young Coconut Water however they were out of it. We ordered the Beef Pho Soup & Lamb Chops. The soup was delicious and plentiful. The Lamb Chops were tender however not very flavorful. Service was fast and attentive. 
Will absolutely go back to Noodle Asia again for a late night Pho fix when at the Venetian.

Alright food... a tad bit over priced.. and bad service!!! 

It took us about 15min to get water(which tasted nasty!), 15min to take our order, 20 more minutes to get our order.... and another 20min to get the bill! And it's not even like they're that damn busy!! 

Oh well...  It did the job of recharging us before the festivities that night, so whatever! ;-) ...now would I come back again? Probably would, but wouldn't be my first choice!

Since we always stay at the Venetian when we go to Vegas, I've hit this spot many times. Food in consistently good, there are a few items that are really good (spicy ying nan noodle, beef rice noodle (add a little soy sauce) and the dim sum). It's also conveniently located close to the poker room. Good hangover food. 
The service is also consistently slow. It's your typical Chinese restaurant service, so when you need something you just need to be vocal!

Super fast service, they delivered my meal so fast I thought they had delivered me someone else order but it was mine. It was hot and tasty and plenty to eat, prices were "ok", not bad for a sit-down restaurant in a casino, a nice place to eat.

Many come to Vegas for the clubs, the casinos, the "naughty naughty" cards off the strip, the palpable indoor cigarette smoke, the shows, or the decriminalized public intoxication and/or prostitution. I come for the Niu Rou Mien at Noodle Asia. Yes, you heard me. I come to Vegas for a hot steamy bowl of chewy noodles, tender chunks of beef, and a deep, dark, bold, spicy broth. 

While yes, at $13.95 for a bowl of Taiwanese soup is quite steep and may leave many wondering where the "happy ending" went; but, rest assured, the happy ending came. And yes, it came without ribbons. It came without tags. It came without packages, boxes or bags. What if Niu Rou Mien, perhaps, means a little bit more? 

In addition, the Red Won Tons tossed in Szechwan Hung Yao chili and garlic sauce are really good too. 

A bowl of Niu Rou Mien is how I do Vegas... and, how the Grinch does Christmas!

This was our first meal in Vegas when we checked into our suite at the Venetian. Disappointed!! :( It tasted worse than Panda Express. Hahah The kitchen and set up of the restaurant looked like a buffet but when you come in, they seat you and take your order. It was really typical "Asian" service at a mom/pop shop that you would find in China town; it was crap. But in Chinatown, at least food is good. Here, food was crap, but at least it wasn't expensive for Vegas. A pro is that the restaurant is open late ... but still, even if I get the late night munchies, I wouldn't come here again.

Noodle Asaaaa sa gud! =)

We came here for lunch and got Saigon noodles, combination fried rice, wonton soup, dim sum, and hot & sour soup. All were good and we were all satisfied. The soups were PERFECT for a night of partying in Vegas. Be sure to ask for the chili oil sauce or something.. it makes everything better!

Place was actually really good the only complaint I have about it was the sports book was right next to it so the smell of cigars is a little rough to eat around. But all and all the food came out the fastest I've ever seen from any restaurant ever and it was delicious

Aside from the price, noodle Asia is actually pretty legit Chinese food on the strip, which is hard to come by.  Usually at other major hotels, you get all the ching chong ling long bells and whistles with big gigantic dragons and red and gold walls everywhere and bastardized noodles.  Rest assured this place actually feels like a classy hole in the wall.  I'm not sure how they achieved that but it's been done.

The spicy beef noodle soup tastes great.  Fat chunks of beef and the noodles are quite chewy.  But if paying a lot for NRM isn't your thing ($14 a lot)...and if you have a car, then you better run over to China town LV.

Since a lot of review talking about the bad service, I am here to tell my experience when I worked at noodle asia. In one year, there were over 100 servers or busers got the job and quit, Why? Bad management! Does a server care to give good customer service when he/she does not feel love from the company? Who care to give a F when they are only consider as a Workers? Here comes a true story, it was the first day for a new buser, after over 4 hours non stop working, time for him to take a break and dinner, he found a dish of fried rice sat in the kichen for over 2 hours due to a special order made wrong, he microwaved it and started eating since only 30 mins break time. The manager on duty found that out, she gave the buser two options: pay for the dish and keep the job, or take the uniform off and leave immediately because he was violating the rule.
For the food, different restaurants prepare their foods in different ways. Some people may like the taste and some don't. It is hard to tell the quarlity since some like extreme spicy and some like extreme the other way.

yay for some soup but BOO on the prices.  What was I expecting though in Vegas at a casino?  HAHA.  

The Szechaun beef noodle soup was pretty spicy but not too shabby.  The dumpling skins were pretty tasty as well - definitely home made! 

I'm sure anyone will frequent this place with a night of drinking.

I've never been a fan of Chinese food, but my friends wanted to eat here. Super greasy, salty and unhealthy. I felt so gross after eating the noodles because it was super greasy. We ordered soup, but it was pretty nasty. Customer service was pretty terrible. I kept on drinking water because of how salty the food was.

The only thing that I crave and order when I feel like a hot bowl of noodle soup is their Sichuan beef noodle soup. The soup is full of flavor, the meat is tender and melts in your mouth and the only complaint I have is that I always want more.....more noodles...more meat....larger bowl. What can I say, I love noodles.

Place is great to eat at since it's open until 3am, so if you don't feel like eating at Grand Lux cafe and are staying at Venetian or Palazzo, walk on over to Noodle Asia and order a bowl. 

Is it the best beef noodle soup....no, you can only find the best in Taiwan...however it'll take care of your cravings while in Las Vegas

It's a "OK" place for Chinese food since their price is a bit on the high size for me. But they do have large menu selection so you can always find something for you. I don't quite like the location which is next to slot machines and people do smoke in there. Can be noisy too.

Order: the sechuan beef, or beef noodle soup. its amazingg. Any of the noodle soups are just great. The cantonese sausage fried rice, made me a believer in chinese sausage. that speaks for itself

Don't order: dumplings, protein dishes like mongolian beef

I HAVE to eat at this place every time I go to Vegas. 'nuff said

My husband has visited Noodle Asia for the last 10 years during his annual conference in Vegas. Today, I got to experience his description of "Oooo, it's so good!" noodle shop for the first time. This place is a fairly reasonably priced Cantonese/Chinese quick eats! Everything is done simple, but well. Portions are nice, quality of food is excellent, ingredients are true to its price point. Most importantly, very yummy, unpretentious authentic local street food cooking in the beautiful Venetian Hotel.  Great place for lunch or a quick bite. Not a formal sit down. Happy Eating!
Excellent soft chicken noodles. Dim sums were safe selections and very tasty. Definitely recommend!

It was late at night and the girls and I were hungry. I ordered won ton noodle soup and it was sooooo good. I don't know if it was because I was a little buzzed or I was super hungry, but it was freaking delicious.

Convenient location in the Venetian Hotel, That's about the only positive thing one can say about this place. Both my visits here have been the same. Average to poor Chinese food, rushed service. Yes it's convenient, that's why I ate here, but I don't think, 3rd time, will be the charm.

Our Chinese Broccoli came out 1st, almost 10 minutes before the rest of our food. Dim sum Shui Mai was was so so, Dan Dan noodles were really disappointing. We paid the bill and still had a half beer to finish, they really wanted to turn our table and rush us out. At least it's not the Americanized Chinese food you get at some places for those who don't know any better.

This is a great place to go after long party night in Vegas and somehow we ended up at Noodle Asia two nights in a row. It's definitely good food after 5 straight hours of dancing and drinking. The prices are a bit high, but the food is actually really authentic. All the dishes are pretty good. The noodle soups, porridge, nian gao and the shrimp xo lai fen are good. The first night we ate there, JH, B and I got there first..ordered our food. Our friend M came by a bit tipsy and cleaned up B's noodle soup. I guess it was pretty darn good to him. The next day, we were walking to Tao through the casino floor, but JH started walking towards Noodle Asia. I guess he really loves it that much! We partied it up at Tao and ended up at Noodle Asia again. Again, good chinese food and the portions are pretty decent. The service is quick too...one thing to note that it closes at 3AM. So, it's open late..but, not vegas-late.

It smells so much better than it tastes!

I still love how nearly every server is Chinese and their English is not so great. That gives it high marks in the authenticity column.  But then, the mix of dishes they have (hence the Asia in the name, as opposed to China), make it so that they do a lot of things decently, but seemingly none of them super well.  (You know, jack of all trades, master of none, kinda thing).  

Being a white girl (and a pale, blonde white girl at that), I feel I have to hyperbolically express how spicy I would like dishes at Asian restaurants, so that they're the normal spice of Asian restaurants. I asked our server if the Ma Po Tofu (very authentic dish I love) is spicy.  She said she didn't know as she doesn't like spicy dishes. It was not spicy, it lacked the Ma La the it should have, and it was fairly bland. Disappointed. The only 'spicy sauce they have if you ask for any is chili oil. 

I'm hoping that Jim G no longer wants to curb his late-night cravings here, as it's just not nearly as good as it smells (but it smells delicious!!!)

Absolutely amazing meal! There was a 20 min wait and it was compensated by the fact that the food was absolutely delicious!

We placed the order and the food came in flat 3 mins or so. It was piping hot and so delicious, this might just be the best Chinese food I have ever had.

The prices are steep as expected from any restaurant in Venetian.We ordered chicken in black bean sauce, vegetable fried rice and vegetable noodles. 

Oh what a dinner, highly recommend!

Nestled in the casino floor at the Venetian, this spot offers some amazing Asian cuisine for a really good price! The staff is very friendly and the food is delicious. I started with the Vietnamese coffee. Omggg amazing! 
For a starter, I went with the potstickers. The sauce that is served with them.... out of this world!!! The pot stickers where perfectly cooked and huge in size. The meat inside was seasoned perfectly. For entree, I ordered the szechwan beef noodle soup. I am soooo happy I listened to the other yelpers for this item. Delicious broth, perfectly cooked beef and just a bowl of happiness. The flavor was unlike any noodle soup I have ever had. My total cost for the meal was $40. 

Definitely worth checking out if you are staying at the Venetian!

My stir fried noodles were a-ok...until I felt sick no less than ten minutes later. I wouldn't have been as upset had I not just paid $16 with tax and tip for a half a plate of noodles and a stomachache. 

After all, I prefer to end my nights in Vegas next to the toilet, not start with it. There are better (and cheaper) places than this.

I eat Dim Sum every sunday in california so when i came across this returant and saw they had dim sum the weekend I was there I desided to try it and wow it was the best I ever had. I am not sure how their other food is but if you get a chance to eat there on a weekend try the Dim Sum and try the duck. it is amazing!

we thought noodles or congee would be a good way to soak up the alcohol after an evening of drinking.  the service here is fast, but the foods is so-so.  i agree w/ bennet a.  overpriced and underflavored.  everything we got was lacking in some flavor, even if the soup looked heavily sauced, there was not much taste.  i got the calamari rice noodle soup, which i thought would come in a clear broth, but it came in a cornstarchy soup w/ egg and green onions.  it was ok but nothing to write home about.
The food is so so, however it is definitely overpriced!!! One noodle plus one fried rice cost $45? Must be kidding!!!

Only place on the strip for Chinese food. Surprisingly good. 

Agree with the others below that this place is probably the only legit Chinese food spot on the strip. The lines can be long but they move fast. The staff and cooks are also Asian so they move fast but don't expect a bunch of wasted chit chat. Just order your noodles and chow down. 

The infamous szechaun beef noodle soup is really on point. Deep, rich and with a slight heat, the beef has got tendon and all. Soft. The noodles are tender, perhaps slightly overdone. But the flavors are thoroughly satisfying. The char sui (BBQ pork) is a bit fatty and they swipe on a different sauce than usual. The dan dan noodles are more peanut and less spicy than most. Just add hit sauce. 

Overall, being smack dab in the Venetian on the strip, the prices are slightly more but given the absolute dearth of reasonably good and not outrageously priced Chinese food, this is your best option to satisfy that craving.

I wish I had taken a picture...the szechuan beef noodle soup was so delicious. The depth of flavor was amazing. Definitely one of the top 5 bowls of noodle soup I've had!! Service was great on top of it. Worth standing in line.

Hey, not bad.

I was actually dreading coming here initially. A huge group of us just flew in to Vegas and now we're starrrrving. We wanted a place closeby, and somehow we stumbled upon it. 

I'm happy to say my food was not drenched in tons of oil or MSG, like usual Asian restaurants! The portions are deceiving, too... it doesn't look like a lot, but it's filling! Especially noodles, since they're carbs.

I recommend the spicy peanut noodles. I'm a sucker for those... definitely not as good as the ones in the bay area, but not complaining. I split it with my friend actually, and it didn't seem like enough, but after a few minutes of sitting around waiting for the check, I felt satisfied. 

I didn't get to try any of the soup noodles, but they all looked pretty good. Seemed like everyone enjoyed their food... lots of leftovers, too!

Great Chinese food (non-chinese food eater), well priced, not greasy, tasty, authentic (from what I'm told), casual.  It was perfect before a night of gambling and trouble.  I didn't expect it to be as good as it was.  A pleasant surprise.

My Ratings:
Quality of Food - 4 Stars 
Quantity of Food - 4 Stars 
Price - 4 Stars 
Location - 2 Stars 
Parking - 3 Stars 
Service - 2 Stars 
Speed - 3 Stars 

My Opinion/Story:
"If you go to Las Vegas, you HAVE to go to Noodle Asia.  They have the best porridge", says my mother.  Coming from my mother who doesn't like rice porridge, I'll have to take her word for it.  So I made a plan to take a trip down to LV.  So last December, my husband and I drove all the way down to LV in my beat-up car.  We stayed for 3 nights and aside from several Vacation Ownerships we attended to get free shows and dinner, we also made a point to visit some of the newer casinos and attempt my luck at the casinos.  Noodle Asia came highly recommended and a MUST try per my mother's standard.  

I had to search for the place since she really didn't remember the name except its the Chinese restaurant in The Venetian.  Being that this is the only one we saw that seems to serve porridge we tried it.  The place looked as messy and beat  up as my car but the hordes of people lining up and eating in this tiny place seems like a good sign.  We got a table after a few minutes.  We couldn't decide what to get so my husband ordered their fried rice and I got their porridge with beef and century egg.  The porridge was really good.  It seems bland at the beginning, probably because I was expecting it to totally blow me away but it grew on me until I couldn't resist not finishing the entire bowl.  

It was made simple but it reminded me of the time my Dad used to take me to Chinatown for a bowl of porridge.  It was delicious.  The service is like any other Chinese restaurant... always in a rush and hard to get them to notice you.  But after a few tries, we were able to get someone to put more water in our glass and finally get us our check.  I'll definitely go back just for the porridge alone but its not a place I'd keep craving for.

We came here because we really wanted noodle soup and this was one of the few still open at 1:30 in the morning. Skip it. The food is not good at all, our congee and noodle soup didn't even come out hot, just warm. The pork + egg congee lacked entirely of flavor, while the szechuan beef noodle soup tasted like they dumped spoonfuls of sugar. Try another spot!

Stopped here after a show and although I am a self proclaimed Asian noodle addict this place was an over the top joy. My wife is much more traditional Chinese food type so she went with the  safe shrimp fried rice. It was good.  I ordered the Shiu Mai with Pai Goo Noodle soup. It's all about the noodles  here.  They were just wonderful.   Service. just OK. They are busy and seem always busy but if real Asian noodles is what your after. ( and most of the other patrons were Asian.  Really a good sign ) This fits the bill. Reasonable price point especially in the heart of the Venetian resort.  Well worth your time

This is a good place for a quick meal. Service was very quick and courteous. I didn't like the fact my soup came out with everyone's entr√©e (versus first and then serve all entrees together) but I am told by my friend who is Chinese that is how they serve the food. Good food at a fair price. Perfect place when you want something tangible but quick.

Went here twice in two days.

First visit:
- service
service was very good, they were prompt, attentive. efficient.

- food
the schezwan style beef noodle soup is DELICIOUS, especially if you like spicy soups. The soup is slightly spicy, there is an abundance of both meat and tendon, and the noodles are cooked extremely well (cooked through, but still a little chewy)

I was thoroughly impressed, and finished the dish soup and all

- misc. (the rest)
the price is a little expensive, but it is on the middle of the strip in the Venetian casino - great location and easy to get to

Second visit:
- service
still good, but they messed up our order

- food
tried to order the schezwan style beef noodle soup, but they brought us the curry beef noodle soup instead... my friend didn't realize but I didn't mind because I had just eaten the beef noodle soup the night before (even though it was so good)

eh.. probably should've sent it back. It was okay, but curry beef noodle soup is not my favorite

- misc.
price is similar, and the location is the same

RECAP:
- the food was pretty good (the curry beef noodle was okay, the schezwan style beef noodle soup was FANTASTIC)
- service (attentive, efficient, fast)
- good location, a little pricier because in the Venetian on the middle of the strip

Added picture

Please.  Don't tell anyone.  I don't want to get in trouble with the "What Happens in Vegas . . ." crowd.  

But it was late.  We had been enjoying ourselves for a long time at the Whiskey Bar.  We were hungry and Noodle Asia was there.  

We both ordered big bowls of noodles.  Nothing for us to drink thank you.  Had enough of that already.  Yes.  Water please.  

Almost before the waiter left the table, our big bowls of delicious noodles arrived.  Hot, fresh, salty, delicious.  It was just what the Dr. ordered.  

I have a feeling it isn't going to hurt as bad tomorrow ... Oh wait, its after midnight?  It isn't going to hurt as bad today when I get up at 11 am to check out of the Hotel all because I had these tasty noodles.

Thank you noodles.  Good night.  Zzzzzzz

We had hot and sour soup, the Szechuan beef noodle soup and the bbq duck & pork with rice.

Typically I hate hot and sour for being too tangy but the soup here even I would eat. The beef noodle soup was hot and salty with chewy noodles. Everything about it was amazing except for the beef.. kindof chewy. The bbq duck & pork was yum as well, it came with steamed bok choy on the side.

Open late for your late night soup noodle cravings! Mm.....

need soup to cure that hangover?? You have a good variety here.  I had the Szechuan Beef Noodle.  It was pretty spicy, but in a good way.  For a meal on the strip, the price point isn't too bad.  The wait staff is friendly and tentative.  They were able to accommodate 10 people pretty easily.  If I'm craving some soup while on the strip, I'll be sure to go back.
We like this place. Everything is pretty good and they're open till late. We especially like their Spicy Beef Noodle. If you like Chinese food, you can't go wrong here.

Pretty good dim sum. Hot and sour soup was just OK. Pot stickers were pretty good too. Nothing to write home about but WAY WAY better than Zine.(the atmosphere was much better at Zine but I will take food over atmosphere anytime!).

Surprisingly, this is one of the best meals in Vegas (especially for the price).  I love the Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup and the potstickers.  And trust me, I wouldn't eat the soup if the meat were gristly (which it is not).

After reading other reviews I'm just going to say, um HELLO of COURSE they put MSG in their food. What good Chinese place doesn't? Why do you think it tastes so good?! If you don't want greasy-MSG-injected food, go have a salad or something. But whatever, you're probably on vacation so you should just go for it and work out when you get home. Or do a few laps up and down the strip.
Anyway, I thought this place was one of the best noodle houses I've been to in Vegas. The BBQ pork and roast duck noodle soup was sooo good. So good....

Very Clean.  Nice service. Variety of selections on their menu.  I had the Szechuan Beef Noodle Bowl and Mike Desort had Pork and Roast Duck Noodle Bowl.  Why does other people's order always look better...?  I couldn't resist...I had to grab some from him...I was enjoying Beef Bowl, but I couldn't keep my eyes off his order...
I would definitely come here again.  The price was reasonable...

I was pretty happy with my dining experience here.  

We came here the morning we left and we wanted something close and in our hotel.  My cousin had mentioned this noodle asia place and it was her place to go to every time she's here so we figured why not!

We got here around the time they opened and shortly they were packed!!

I got the Beef Noodle Soup which is very much like the taiwanese style beef noodle soup and i wasn't disappointed at all!  A little oilier than what I'm used to but the broth seemed cleaner than what I'm also used to which was a plus!  They weren't shady on the beef either!  The bowl was a little pricey of course!  But hey, being in the Palazzo, what do you expect. My pretty little beef noodle soup cost me $17 with tax and tip!  Yikes!  Being asian, I know that I can get a bowl like this for $7 but oh well, it's vegas!

My cousin got the duck noodle soup and she said her duck was really salty.

My other friend who came along got the shanghai noodles which looked way too oily for me!
great service.  Good food.  The noodle soups were fabulous.

I was really craving Chinese food after a long weekend in Vegas filled with drinking, gambling, and general debauchery. In comes Noodle Asia. 

What I ended up experiencing was a) poor service (even though the restaurant was half full) b) bland food c) high prices 

Our server forgot our waters for about 15 minutes, brought all our meals out at separate times, and took 20 minutes to pick up our check after she brought it to the tabe. Talk about mind being elsewhere. Actually, let me reprase: Our server never came back to get our check, we had to flag the manager down after 20 minutes of waiting. 

In terms of food... bleh. I had the broccoli and beef with spring rolls on the side. I can safely say I've had $5.99 Chinese takeout meals that have been way better. The food really had no flavor to it, and I had to douse it with duck sauce and other spices to coax any sort of taste out of the dish. 

 Maybe it's my strictly American palette, but I think I've become accustomed to Americanized Asian food and get really thrown off when authentic Asian food is put in front of me. Who knows? 

What I do know is that I wouldn't be back, and would recommend all Vegas-goers to skip over Noodle Asia in favor of the food court nearby.

Yang Chou Fried Rice was decent and came in a surprisingly large portion with plenty of shrimp!  Now that is value for a restaurant inside a Las Vegas strip hotel!!

Vegetarian Pan Toasted Noodles was not good.  The Chinese name is Lo Han Chay stir fried noodles.  Thus, my expectation was Chinese vegetables, shitake mushrooms, maybe some wheat gluten (vegetarian meat).  What I got was canned chop suey vegetables (water chestnut, canned mushrooms) over noodles.  But the portion was large.

FOOK GEEN CHOW FAN. (Fried rice, crack sauce, mushrooms, veggies, shrimp, and more good shit. CANNOT GO WRONG! It's off the menu but we get this EVERY time we go to vegas. Best hangover food you can get. & it's location is awesome!
Pretty decent dim sum and wonton soup.  A good choice if you're getting a bit tired of Vegas food.

This place finally satisfied my congee craving! It was so good! I'll definitely go back!

PLUS, it was a short stroll from TAO Beach where we happened to imbibe a little too much and hence, we ended up very much in need of carbs to soak up the alcohol! :P

Great food! Polite staff!  Our order came out fast.
My husband had the Szechuan beef soup.  The beef was super tender, like ribs or pot roast and very flavorful.  I

The potstickers were homemade and delicious!  Larger than normal and the dipping sauce was outstanding. 

Kimchee was great and a very large portion.

I had wonton noodle soup dish and it was good and filling.

Tea was great...water glasses were always full.

Coincidently located in the Venetian.

No complaints at all!  Great place to fill your belly before gambling!

Holy Wong Fei Hong Batman!  This place is popping with Asians and Asian noodles! Pow!  

Don't know Wong Fei Hong, no worries I gather many "Westerners" wouldn't.  However, they do know one thing -- this place.  Noodle Asia is located inside the Venetian Hotel in Vegas.  I wouldn't think such a restaurant exists in The Venetian, but you know what; it works!

Noodle Asia reminds me of the 24 hour cafes located in California.  After a night out for drinks you need some grease!  Noodle Asia has all the classic Asian dishes from Shanghai, Black Peppered, Fried Rice, and Dim Sum too!  Needless to say, this place doesn't play around when it comes to Chinese food.  Tab bit overpriced in my opinion for what you get simply because the protein almost drowned out by the carbs.  Granted I enjoy my carbs, just not too much.  Also, is it me or do I need to drink a lot of water after a meal here?  I guess what I'm trying to say is that it's salty!  Guess that goes well for the "American" diet.  

There seems to be a line during the day which is not bad.  The restaurant is located right next to the sports betting area so a quick glance over to see the score is awesome. - Enjoy!

FOOD
- Saut√©ed Chicken With Broccoli: the chicken was tender but lacked flavor. The Chinese broccoli was a little more crunchier than I like. I was not liking this dish in my drunken state. lol. 2.75/5

- Boneless Chicken Breast Congee: I didn't like my dish so my friend shared her congee with me. It was amazing! It was probably one of the best congee I've ever had. She saved me from a disappointing dining experience. 5/5

SERVICE
Fast and fair. 3.5/5

FINAL THOUGHTS
I would come back for more congee or to try other dishes. It's overpriced Chinese food but, hey, it's Vegas. It wasn't outrageously expensive.

One word: OVERPRICED.

But given that you're in Vegas.... what isn't overpriced? The food is actually decent and is probably one of the most authentic Chinese food you can find directly on the strip.

I've only ever ordered one thing: the beef noodle soup. Spicy, flavorful filled with beef & tendon, thin noodles and topped with some green onion and Taiwanese sour cabbage. For $14, it's a major rip off but it definitely hits the spot and it's so good that I can actually finish the whole bowl myself. I tried sharing once and.... let's just say ... THAT was a mistake. I have pretty high standards for beef noodle soup and I definitely like this one.

Speaking of mistakes, don't make this one. As an Asian person, I'm used to ordering a round of water or hot tea for everyone at the table. One time upon ordering tea, the waiter asked me "how many cups for the tea? " and I told him "8, for everyone at the table." - also thinking.... don't you just bring a big pot of tea? ANYWAYS well, I was not informed that tea cost like $2-$3 PER CUP PER PERSON. So after he brought 8 cups and only 4 of us actually drank the tea.... but we still got charged for 8 cups of tea! So ridiculous!! Lesson learned.

They've also remodeled since I came last and it looks GREAT! Definitely looks more Vegas and gives a more modern/clean look. Service is ok, could be better.

Sober or drunk.... the beef noodle soup is good. 3.5 stars for good noodles, nice atmosphere and location in the Venetian and... good noodles.

Our favorite place to go for a late night meal after going out. The noodles soups are super good! I like the wonton noodle soup. The roast duck/pork noodle soup is also amazing. 
The prices are not too bad for how much food you get. 
Other items are also good, including the lettuce wraps.

Absolutely the best cuisine ever!!!  We ordered edamame, chicken lettuce wraps, beef and broccoli, and pan fried noddles extra crispy with chicken. The flavors were divine and the meals were fresh. Service was fast and courteous. We never received the edamame so it was taken off our bill. We didn't have room for it after the other food we ate. We had plenty of leftovers and ended up bagging them up for a few homeless people on the strip. Can't wait to go back--yum!!!!

When I got to Las Vegas I was feeling a little under the weather. When I feel that way I always crave soup. At Noodle Asia I ordered a large vegetable noodle soup with fried tofu. It had a great variety of exotic mushrooms and veggies in a delicate broth. The noodles had a big, complex flavor. I couldn't get enough and ate until I was too full. Despite that, I had left overs to eat later that night in the hotel room. I thought the menu had something for everyone, the food was good, and the price was reasonable.

This place is the bomb, people. If you want either 1) very authentic chinese food or 2) a very reasonably priced hot meal - this is your place! It is inside the Venetian near the poker room. 

-If you don't know want to get but want to keep it delicious and simple: go with the fried rice or a chef's specialty (i.e. Kung Pao)

-If you want to be a real ass mandarin: get some rice porridge or a noodle bowl

price point: $12-20
closes @ 3am

I live in LA where the Asian food is cheap and awesome.   So of course compared to that,  this place would be very disappointing.   Perhaps it's unfair to rate them so low.   After all,  I am Asian and had only the best Asian food.  

Still,  it's hard to give them a better rating when a simple standard dish such as Mapo tofu and Hot and sour soup was horrid.  Soup was overly sour and the Mapo tofu had no taste.   It just tasted like tofu with cornstarch cooked into it.  No flavor.  None.  Maybe some salt?   The crispy noodles and Mongolian beef was decent.   I added an extra star because these two dishes were borderline food court level.   The shu mai dimsum appetizer was also decent but nothing special.  $9 for 6 pieces.    Every dish was around $15+ but that's because it's inside a hotel.   All the cooks and servers were Asian.  Service was Asian like.   That means it was below average.   Don't expect superb food,  ambience or service here.   If it weren't for my father in law wanting to give this place a try,  I'd rather go eat at Panda express.

Desperate for food was more like it...after walking from Monte Carlo all the way to the Venetian till 2am our party was starving.
I was reluctant to have chinese food here in Vegas since Toronto by far till this day has the best Chinese food.

Service was a 2/5, our server seemed a bit snobbish, and was not at all a people-person.  Perhaps its the the "AM" time which was getting to him.  However the female manager who came by to serve our food was very pleasant, and indeed a cutie with a twinkle in her winkle lol.....

I had the night market fried rice 4/5: sliced beef tossed in thai chilli, basil, bean sprouts, and diced tomatos was yumm!! perfect balance of flavors, however the beef slices could have been smaller.  Each slice was half a mouthful lol...

BBQ Pork & Duck Noodle Soup 2/5: Barely any duck, and a few slices of bbq pork, the presentation was great, but honestly not worth it.

Fu Chow Fried Rice 3/5: presentation, taste, and portion was bang on! lots of shrimp, chicken, mushroom, calamari, and scallion gravy...worth it!!

Overall the quality of the dishes were below my expectations.  This restaurant almost seemed like a waste of space that lacked the taste. Sorry Venetian

Legit, affordable, authentic Chinese joint in Vegas. Great for rice dishes w/ bbq and hot noodles/ noodle soups after the club. I get real nostalgic for these dishes because it's the stuff I ate growing up! Real Chinese food AND it's the best hangover prevention! I had the wonton noodle soup, and it piping hot and delicious. My friend let me try some of her sliced rice cakes, and they were PERFECT. Would definitely be back. Highly recommend.
I still say Dan Dan Noodles should be listed under Soups. Otherwise, the food is excellent and the Red Wontons are to die for! We stop here whenever we're in Vegas.

I've heard all the hype about Noodle Asia and how it easily compares to Noodles at the Bellagio but I couldn't really see that as I finished my meal. The first issue I have is that it has the feel of a greasy casino kitchen mainly because it's located inside the sportsbook at the Venetian. 

Another big issue I have is that I couldn't really decipher what half of the menu contained. Some of the menu items had a description while others just listed their name. Now if I knew what they were this would be no issue but sadly I couldn't really figure out what to order and just ended up picking some random noodle dish with beef. I probably ordered cat, I honestly have no fucking clue!

The dish itself was delicious and I felt like I ate a portion that was easily made for 3-4 people. OOPS! It was a bit spicy but not to the point of crying, although there is nothing wrong with a few tears while dining. My friend swears by their shrimp fried rice so I tried some and wasn't blow away at all. If I closed my eyes I could have sworn I was in a panda express that added shrimp. Maybe next time I will dine with someone who can interpret the menu and guide me through the jungle that is Noodle Asia.

If you enjoy below average noodle dishes this place is for you. We went here thinking it would be a reasonably priced meal before our show and we were less than impressed across the board. Calamari balls appetizer were better suited for playing jacks. The noodles were spectacularly unimpressive. They brought us a plate with basil so wilted we had to ask for some fresh to use for or meal.
The only thing good about the whole experience was that it didn't last to long and it has a big window looking out to the sports book.
Don't waste your time or your money there's a McDonalds upstairs.

Chinese is not my favorite but this place really does it well. The services is very fast. From sitting down to ordering and getting your food quickly it's awesome. I mostly eat fish and its not on the menu but yes they can do a fish plate. I asked for veggies on the side. It was all sauteed in garlic which I also asked for. It was very good, just what I wanted. Only 4 stars cause it is expensive for Chinese food.

After days and days of burgers in Las Vegas, we were a bit tired of it and wanted something Asian (we actually missed Asian food soo sooo much!!) 
We came across this restaurant by accident but when my parents' friends saw it, they immediately decided to have dinner there. They said they really wanted a hot bowl of noodle soup. There wasn't a lineup so we got seated really quickly. It took them a while to bring us tea. In fact, my dad had to ask the waiter for it. I wouldn't say the waiter was super friendly and attentive. While he was taking our orders, he was just looking at other tables, which I find was unprofessional.

The menu has a big variety of dishes ranging from congee to noodle soup, from fried rice to dim sum, etc. It took me a little while to decide what I wanted because there were a lot of dishes that I like. I finally decided to try their Cantonese Beef Stew Noodle soup (???). My sister ordered their Fish Filet congee (???) because she wasn't feeling well and congee is easier to digest. My mom ordered their Snow Cabbage with Enoki Mushroom and Fried Tofu Noodle Soup (?????????). My dad and my parents' friends all opted for their Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup (???????). I wanted to order the beef noodle soup but I was scared it would be too spicy so I didn't get it.
My Cantonese Beef Stew Noodle soup (???) came with wonton noodles (also called wanton mee). Some people, like my mom, dislike the flavor of this kind of noodle but I'm fine with it. I liked how the texture of this noodle is firmer and thus, chewier. The dish came with only 2 baby bok choy... I definitely would enjoy more vegetables here. The beef stew was flavorful but it wasn't the best I've ever had. I didn't like the fact that half of my portion of meat was just fat. I was expecting more tendons and meat for the price I paid (pay $15 USD). They also cut the meat in small pieces, which made it seem like there were a lot of mean in this bowl. 

My sister's Fish Filet congee (???) congee was pretty good but definitely not worth the price considering the amount of fish filet she had. It was just a decent bowl of congee but nothing too special about it.

My mom's Snow Cabbage with Enoki Mushroom and Fried Tofu Noodle Soup (?????????) was.... I don't even know how to describe it. It definitely didn't look like what she had imagine! It looked really messy with enoki and cabbage all spread out and floating around... It originally came with wonton noodles but since my mom doesn't like this kind of noodle, she exchanged it for Lai Fun (??). This bowl of noodle soup didn't taste bad but definitely not worth its price considering there wasn't a piece of meat and all the ingredients are not expensive at all...
 It seems like their Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup (???????) is a must there but you will be quite disappointed, especially if you've had the beef noodle soup from Asia or Taiwan before! It is just not comparable!! It was tasteful but still lacking flavor as compared to any of the beef noodle soup restaurants in Taiwan. I highly suggest anyone to visit Taiwan because this country is a food heaven!

In short, there aren't many Asian restaurants on Las Vegas Strip, if you are tired of Panda Express and would like something classier (conveniently located inside The Venetian Hotel, on the same level as their casino and beautifully decorated) and more expensive, Noodle Asia is the place to go! I don't think the price justified the quantity and quality of their food but it was nonetheless a satisfying meal for us.

My third time getting the Szechuan noodle soup and it's still good as prior times. It's $15.00 but always hits the spot after drinking and open till 3 am. Hand made noodles and you can taste the difference. Last night had too much tendon but it was 2:30 in the morning so maybe they were running low. Still a great spot to get some Chinese food

Whatever you do DO NOT EAT HERE!! My husband and I ate here on 2/5/17 after the Super Bowl and we both got the worst food poisoning of our lives. We both ordered dim sum for appetizers and the Wonton Noodle for our main meal. To be fair I think it was the dim sum not the noodles that got us sick, but regardless I would advise against ever eating here. We were supposed to fly out the following day but we got so sick that we had to reschedule our flights for the next day and had to stay an additional day at the Venetian costing us over $400 total. In case you don't believe me we even filed a formal complaint with the hotel for future records. If I could give this place zero stars I would. BEWARE OF THIS PLACE!! STAY AWAY!!

I've only been to 3 noodle places in Vegas, but Noodle Asia has been the best so far.  The others I've tried are Noodles at Bellagio and Beijing Noodle #9 at Caesars.

It seems like we always go here on a late Friday night after coming from the airport.  The dishes I've had have all been really good.  The noodles in the Szechwan Beef are amazing..  really fresh.  The Chicken Stir-Fried Soft Noodles are pretty good.  Probably my favorite is the Buddha Feast Pan-Toasted Noodles.  My gf gets it all the time cuz it's vegetarian, but you can add meat (I like mine with chicken..  it comes out to be the same price as the Chicken Stir-Fried Soft Noodles).  Every time I get something other than that, I end up wishing I'd just gotten it instead.

Noodles at Bellagio also has pan-toasted noodles.  I think they call it Hong Kong style noodles, or Cantonese noodles, or something like that.  I don't know whether it was a fluke, but contrary to Noodle Asia's, they were gross.  Extremely salty.  Like salty enough for your mouth to feel like it's getting too much salt, and for you to wonder whether your blood pressure will be adversely affected by it.  blech.

Back to Noodle Asia.  They run a tight ship.  Service is prompt and good.  You can see them cooking your food.  The food is good.  It might seem a little pricey for what it is, but it's worth it I think.  All around an excellent place.

We ate here a couple of times while staying at the Palazzo. 

The decor and ambiance aren't anything special, but that is not the draw, its the noodles. 

My two favorite noodles were the spicy ying ran rice noodle and the XO shrimp lai fen. Both had intense flavors and were probably enough to share. 

Stay away from the szechwan beef noodle soup. I think that was really greasy beef, or all gelatinous fat. Just not right. 

Service was fast and efficient. It does get pretty busy around lunch so get there early.

I thought this place was great!  Right near the casino at the Palazzo, but didn't feel casino-y.  :)  Prices very reasonable.  A friend and I shared a bowl of beef noodles, couple of spring rolls and crab rangoon and it was more than enough food.   The service was great, the price was very reasonable and it just really hit the spot after a long day.  I saw someone else's noodle soup, and knew I would get that next.  Nothing fancy, but  I thought the food was great.  Would definitely go back.
Authentic Chinese Food. ???? and ??? both taste good. Good place for people living in Venetian.

My favorite place to eat in Vegas!  When you're dehydrated, hungover and exhausted and probably hungry b/c you haven't had a square meal all weekend, Noodle Asia is the perfect place to go!  A meal here works wonders!  I love their shrimp fried rice and schechwan beef noodle soup (add some white vinegar)!

This is a nice place to grab some carbs while you are doing your Vegas thing.  The flavors are OK.  The fried rice needed a lot of doctoring up at the table to be good though.  The shrimp fried noodles were pretty good.  Really liked the spring rolls.  It's basically a sit down fast food place though so expect to get shuffled in and out as fast as possible.  Which was OK for us but others shouldn't expect lovely, attentive service.  They just get things done.

I am pleasantly surprised. My friend and I ordered the Pepper Beef and the Hong Kong Won Ton here. The food arrived within seven minutes and raised no complaints, at all - just the opposite. The Won Ton was delicious; the Pepper Beef was amazing. The meat was cooked just right and so, so soft, I ate more than I usually do! I deeply appreciate that the food here is not as greasy as that in many other Chinese restaurants I have eaten at. 

The decoration of the place and the uniforms of the servers and chefs are distinctly Chinese and add a nice cultural touch to customers' dining experience. The walls of the restaurant are made of glass, so customers can sit down inside and eat while observing sports games on the big screen outside. There are seats positioned facing outward from the restaurant for precisely that purpose. I imagine that is a huge plus for sports enthusiasts. 

Our server wasn't too talkactive or smile-y, but he was quick and attentive, which is all I need in a waiter. I always had water in my glass, and we never even had the time to notice the lack of anything before he put it on our table. 

Prices are pretty average for a restaurant is on the strip, nothing that should come as a shock to anyone. Many of the meat dishes are served with rice, and the chefs have no issue adjusting the spiciness level for customers.

the food was alright but definitely cost more than it should.  we went for a quick lunch and the service was alright too but the food was not up to par with your typical vegas food.  btw don't get the kim chee, not good.

Over priced Chinese food.  It's a great place to eat between 12-3 AM.  But other than that time time slot, I don't think I'd pay so much for white-washed Chinese food. Especially considering Panda Express is not that far away.

I love this place go there every time I am in town just haven't gotten around to write a review.
Food is a tad bit on the higher side but taste wise it is right on the money.
Service can be a bit slow on a weekend lunch time.
This is what I love on the menu 
Fire house chicken wings
Shanghai style noodles 
Wonton soup 
King pao shrimp or chicken 
Seafood fried rice
Dim Sum

Very poor service with little portion for a very expensive charge for the food. Not to mention they give u pressure when u order the food, as if u don't order a lot seems you are cheap. Did nor enjoy the food or the atmosphere here. Bad bad bad...

Our absolute favorite Chinese food in any city we have been to. The dipping sauce for the gyoza is amazing! I get orange chicken and LOVE it and hubby can't get enough of the kung pao chicken. Their chicken is such high quality- no disgusting fatty pieces. Well worth the money. We don't visit Vegas without eating here.

During a fun filled bachelorette weekend of partying, my friend & I left the club early just to try this place out right before they closed at 2am. Thankfully we made it and it was worth running in heels for. We ordered the duck noodle soup. I'm not kidding you, the broth is god sent and amazing and the noodles were delectable! It was worth the $13 price tag. The bowl was large enough to share between us two girls and left us wanting more. The cool thing was that we weren't even drunk to have to enjoy some delicious comfort food!
Loved the rice and the chicken dishes. Would like to try again. Nice restaurant located in venetian

Whoa! Why didnt I know about this place before!? Took a random trip to Vegas this weekend. Lost my friends at Tao so I some how ended up here at the noodle spot and I asked what was the most popular dish. The lady picked out Szechwan Beef noodle soup. And it was damn good! Serious flavor going on here and the noodles were good. Actually came back the 2nd day with my friend and got roasted duck and bbq pork noodle soup. This place definitely hits the spot :)
Had reservations at 1015 pm.  Late by 15 minutes.  Waited 2 hours after that.  Sounds more of a night club than a restaurant.  I was the fool.
REALLY bland food. I had the egg rolls which were virtually tasteless.  No Chinese mustard served, so there was no way to spice them up. The Dan Dan noodles had a little spice but were pretty boring.

I came to this restaurant on friday lunch with my cousin and it was disappointing.. With service and food!

We were craving Asian food so much and we were staying Venetian so it was close and looked pretty nice! 

We ordered chef's special both were noodles 
My cousin's food came out super quick but it took forever for my food to come out to the point where my cousin finished her food and still didn't come out. We asked the waitress to check our food and we still had to wait for another 15mins. Finally my food came out and before I even finished, waitress came by and gave us the check and asked me if i need a box for my food when I'm not even done eating so I thought that was pretty rude. 

Overall food was okay and they need more improvement on the service.

I wasn't expecting much from this restaurant, other than ok quality food with a high price for what it is. Surprisingly, the two noodle dishes we ordered were actually very good. I had Szechuan-style Beef noodle soup, which can be had for around seven dollars in California, but was around 13 dollars here. The noodles were a little weird, but the beef and soup were so delicious. The beef was actually very good quality with quite a bit of fat (which is apparently the correct style for this noodle soup). I gobbled it up. My dining mate had BBQ pork and duck noodle soup, which I wasn't particularly a fan of, but she said it was good (particularly the quality of the meats).

The food itself was potentially of five-star quality for one of those quick sit and go restaurants in Vegas, but considering that it's about double the price and not THAT higher quality, I can only give it four stars.
Service was friendly and fast. Food was pretty terrible and overpriced. Disappointing to say the least.

I've ate here a lot in the past.   I wouldn't go out of my way for it, but if I'm hungry, and they're in front of me, I'll find myself sitting down at one of their tables.  

Good stuff.  Dishes I remember my grandmother making.  But nothing that compared to her recipes

after clubbing at tao on friday night, a few of us passed by noodle asia on the way back to our room and decided to try it out, although we weren't sure how good an asian place in the venetian would be. it turned out to be a great choice!! here are the dishes we ordered:

hong kong won ton soup: delicious!! came with a huge mass of egg noodles and several shrimp (and maybe pork?) won tons
pork & special preserved egg congee: YUM
hot & sour soup: a bit too sour, nothing special
beef rice noodles (beef chow fun): a little bland but otherwise YUMMY

we tried to go again on sunday around 6 pm and there was a line so we went to the sad food court instead. :( next time i'm in vegas i will definitely stop by again for yummy chinese food!

Pretty authentic Chinese food on the strip and it's open late. Better than I expected. 

We came in at 2am on a Wednesday. They're open until 3am on Wednesday. It wasn't busy at all and we were seated immediately. The waiter promptly greeted us and made some appetizer suggestions. We went with edamame and red wontons. The edamame was cooked with anise and had a good flavor. Even better when you make a sauce mix from the soy sauce and hot pepper sauce on the table and dip the edamame in it. The red pork wontons were very flavorful too. Very good.

The food came out so quickly and was piping hot. I thoroughly enjoyed my Cantonese beef noodle soup. The noodles were cooked just right, fresh baby bok choy, tender beef and tendon, and hearty broth. Just the way I like it. Yes, it's a little pricy for Chinese food but it's expected being on the strip and located in the gorgeous Venetian hotel and casino. 

I wouldn't hesitate to come back for some more noodle soup. Really want to try the schezuan beef noodle soup based on the other Yelp reviews. Next time for sure!

This trip I tried their spring rolls and they were on point. 
I also tried their mixed vegetable noodle soup, and it was super satisfying!!  Man, I love this place...

Very pleasantly surprised....it was good!
I had a black bean crispy noodle with beef...a little spicy and very tasty....the portions were very generous.  Ordered a won ton mein for my husband...again, generous portion and tasted very authentic...meaning, like the kind of Chinese won ton mein we eat at home...
People were nice and prices seemed to be fair.
beef noodle soup is surprisingly good but waaaay to expensive for this kind of food.  You cant really complain since you are out in the desert though.

We were ignored for 20 minutes after arriving at our table. Normally I wouldn't be so bothered when I have good conversation at the table but the fact that tables that were seated after us were having their drink orders taken and delivered before I had even seen my waiter was irritating. I had to go find a waitress a total of three times before the hostess decided to just come and take our order herself. Our food came out about fifteen minutes later and our drinks finally came out an additional 10 after that (sadly I actually kept track). No one ever came to refill any of our drinks. The only thing that made me feel a little better is that I wasn't the only one who  was receiving this type of service. Three other tables also had to either get up and find someone to take their orders or find someone to print out their checks because they weren't being attended to. Maybe this was just a bad night for Noodle Asia but as far as I'm concerned with horrible service and mediocre food I don't think I will ever return. 

Nooooo Thanks. I'll get my noodles somewhere else.

It was a very disappointing dining experience. There was a long line for this restaurant (and decent reviews on Yelp), which is usually a promising sign, but the food was really terrible. One of the dishes I ordered was the famous beef noodle soup that other reviewers wrote about, but the broth was heavily dilated with water and there was no flavor at all. After the lunch, all four of us felt the effect of MSG in the food. Compared to all the other wonderful meals we had in Vegas, this one turned out to be a huge mistake.

Let ne start with me saying that the food is great but the service was horrible. The busser spilled hot water all over my back and my coat that was resting on the back of the chair. Instead of apologizing or helping to clean he pretended like nothing happened and walked away. We then told the waitress and she didnt seem to care at all either. She was actually more concerned about cleaning the floor so no one trips and sues them than to apologize or help me dry my shurt or coat. If i ever come back it will definitely be to go.

When you're not sure what time it is, and you need to reload with some carbs and electrolytes while still wearing your PJ's and slippers, or club dress and hat borrowed from someone whose name you can't remember. If one of your fake lashes is barely hanging on, if you're not sure what happened to your other shoe....this is a good place to go.

The service is pretty fast.  It's solid middle of the road fare.  These won't be the best noodles of your life, but they won't kill you.  The service is FAST.  This is not the place for your fancy night out in Vegas, it's where you go because you're hungry and NEED to eat SOON.  Ummm, and you can play Keno at the table.

What a ripoff! I thought that this classy place in the Venetian with astronomical prices for Chinese food might at least be good, but I had what was one of the most expensive and worst bowls of rice porridge here. 

For $11 a bowl, I expect an incredible pork and preserved egg porridge. What I got:
Watery flavorless porridge with about 1/4 of preserved egg and some stewed pork. You'd think at this price, one would get a whole preserved egg. Seriously stingy.  The pork was good, that's why it even has any stars.
First time coming the food looked and smelled amazing so I had to give it a try! Just finished my Szechuan beef with noodles, o yes I will be back!

I really enjoyed my lunch combo of Mandarin duck / soy sauce chicken.  They were very authentic preparations, like Hong Kong / Singapore Street food.  Lots of bones, but that is how the dishes are made.  Very tasty and reasonable, especially compared to the nearby food court steam table stuff.  Some dishes get up there, but very few over $20, so not bad for right in a casino.

Wasn't impressed.  Long line outside, and seeing the number of Asians eating inside, I thought it was a good sign.  But after 30 minutes of waiting in line and watching the servers completely fumbling over each other - they were clearly inexperienced and had no idea what they were doing, I knew we were doomed.  But we had already waited that long so we stayed.  From the line, I watched table after table trying to flag someone down because they wanted to pay.  No one would come to them.  I look over to see where the servers are and all four servers, standing together near the cash register looking completely flustered.  Meanwhile, there is a gigantic line outside, which is continuing to grow, and tables are empty and cleared and no one is coming to address the customers waiting in line.  Finally, after about 40 minutes, the man in front of me started to get annoyed obviously by seeing pretty much half the restaurant clear out and no one being seated so he walks in to the four servers standing around the cash register and says something to them.  Finally, one server comes and takes that man and his friend and seats them at the counter.  Then she goes back to standing there - like deer in headlights.  Good grief. Then it was my turn to flag the girl down and tell her that I am happy to sit at the counter as there are empty chairs.  When I tell her that, then she seats us, finally.   I have no idea how long the others continued to wait outside. 

Once at the counter, we ordered, two noodle soup dishes.  it was pretty uneventful and unflavorful.  Maybe it was what I ordered, or maybe it was because they were so busy that they were rushing and not preparing food properly.  

We ate here because we watched Rock of Ages at the Venetian.   I don't think I would ever come back here again.  For noodles - I much prefer Noodles at Bellagio!

Food- 5/5 Probably as authentic as you're gonna find in Vegas

Value- 3/5 Definitely not cheap chinese food. 

Ambiance- Nothing special

Service- No complaints

DISHES TASTED

Red Won Tons- 4/5 Good flavor

Szechwan Beef- 5/5 AMAZING. One of the best beef noodle soup I've had in the US.

Shanghai Noodle- 3/5 Nothing special

Absolutely perfect... Nothing beats a bowl of spicy well made broth with freshly made noodles and tender beef. The Szechwan beef bowl was exactly what I was looking for as a late night meal. 
My wife had the miso soup which was also above expectations but I don't think I'll ever be able to resist the Szechwan beef.

This is an ideal place on the strip when you are craving some legit Chinese noodle soup either for drunk munchies (since they are open late), or for a hangover cure.  By legit, I mean all the staff tha works here are Chinese, including the cooks.  

I had the beef noodle stew, which came with preserved cabbage and large chunks of beef, some dense feeling hand tossed noodles, and a really really good broth base.  Perfect for hangovers.  My girl had the preserved egg and pork porridge.  It tasted almost as legit as my mom's.  We shared the bok choy with oyster sauce, which was perfectly boiled.  

The only thing is that this place is pretty expensive.  Our bill was almost fifty dollars, for what would cost only fifteen to twenty in Chinatown somewhere.  But, keep in mind you are eating in the Venetian.  

PROTIP:  Large portions, so share!

I used to work a booth at the ASD trade show at the Sands Convention Center two weeks out of the year. My company would order take out for lunch from here almost everyday. It's just your ordinary overpriced Chinese food. Nothing tastes great, but nothing tastes horrible. It sure beats eating old hot dogs from the convention center.

This place was bomb! Not sure if it had anything to do with dancing all night or drinking a Fat Tuesday but it was good and the only place open in that hotel but Tao. Got jasmine tea, noodles and rice I believe. This was over ahead ago.

We came here on our first night in Vegas, as we were staying at the Venetian.  The food was cheap (for the Strip), and the quality the same.  We got a variety of dim sum items incl. bbq pork, some noodles, and won ton soup I think.  I remember the food not being particularly fresh, and perhaps even a bit cold.  Definitely not up to par for a Bay Area palette, but why'd I come to Vegas to eat "Chinese" food anyway?

This place is conveniently located inside The Venetian Casino. We came around 8pm on a saturday evening and it was not packed...yet.  The service was not very good because the guy kept forgetting us and rushing us to order. However, once we got the order placed--the dishes came by super fast.

We ordered:
- Chicken/Mushroom Noodle Soup
- Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce
- Shrimp Dumplings
- Hot and Sour Soup
- Cold Jelly Fish Side dish


The Chicken/Mushroom soup came in a nice portion sized bowl and it was not cheap. My dad said the flavor was good , but my mom preferred my hot and sour soup better. There were lots of chicken and mushroom bits in the soup and it was hot (temperature). 

The Chinese broccoli was excellent, the sauce wasn't generously drizzled on the broccoli which we preferred. The dish was a hit and i would've ordered that again if i came the next time.

The Shrimp dumpling (dim sum) was good, but not worth the price. It came lukewarm or not even warm. The dumplings were sticking with each other. but, nonetheless it was food. 

Hot and sour soup was a hit for my mom and I. I liked it , there were lots of flavor and it gave a kick (spicyness).  I would order this again, but for 5 bucks for a cup is SUPER EXPENSIVE. the cup was not a big cup..so get a bowl if you're hungry. 

the jelly fish was a slight dissapoint out of all the dishes we tried. It lacked flavor and it wasn't as crunchy as I would have liked it. 

Overall, we had a good experience, it's legit chinese food that I missed while staying at LV. Definitely not like LA , but its vegas and food is not cheap. I still would come back and try their spicy beef noodle soup. yum!

Of course I had noodles! It's a nice quick bite. The noodles were massive and pretty good. I liked the generous amount of veggies. Service was quick and friendly. A tad pricey ($20 for a plate) but standard for vegas fast food. It's a decent place to grab a quick bite for lunch.

Used to come here a lot and always found the food to be good but the service to be horrible.  Lo and behold, they listened to the complaints and really upped the service to beyond good, it's actually amazing.  

Great food, great service.  Didn't give it 5 stars because it's expensive.
Took a break from gambling and tried this spot for lunch - sat at the bar. The BEST pork dumplings I've ever had... I'm still thinking about them months later! They were just that good.
Noodle Asia is a great alternative to the heavy and fast food alternatives at The Venetian Hotel. Their food is fresh and flavorful. Excellent!!

One of the more affordable places on the strip. Not the best ambiance since it's right next to the Venetian sports book, but hey it's Vegas. Classically prepared dishes. Had the wonton noodle soup and beef rice noodle. Will continue to visit here.

Can't go to Vegas without going to a good noodle restaurant. My favorite is the one located inside the Bellagio, but got good recommendations about the Noodles Asia located inside the Venetian. 

So there we went.

Awesome food.

Portions are huge. Me and my companion enjoyed every bit of our meals.

Service can be a bit slow because it gets crowded. But be patient and you will be rewarded.

Prices are very reasonable.

here's a quick summary: over-priced and under-flavored. 

i would have never come here if i weren't an asian staying at venetian, did have a rental car to venture out, or weren't struck with an asian food craving.

Nothing we had here was amazing, but several dishes were just plain awful.  The jellyfish, the curry fish balls and the wonton noodle soup were absolutely disgusting.  As hungry as we were, we didn't even eat a second bite of it.  We even asked if it was supposed to taste like that (they said yes).  The prices are actually not too bad for a restaurant inside the Venetian.  They are open pretty late too.

I didn't have insanely high expectations for this restaurant, as it's located right on the casino floor inside the Venetian. The atmosphere was well done,  and it did have a reasonable selection of traditional and mildly exotic Pan Asian choices. 

The food itself was average, though the prices were quite high. We ordered kung pao chicken and orange chicken, and one soda. The bill was over $50.

The portion sizes were large, but the taste was very run of the mill. I don't mind paying extra for quality, but it just wasn't there. 

I didn't find the service particularly good either. My entree was brought out  about 10 minutes prior to my wife's without apparent cause, and we had to actively flag down or waitress for a water refill or to get the check. 

I don't believe this restaurant would remain in business if not for the convenience factor of its location. There are many,  many other excellent choices in the Venetian complex alone. I personally would have been happier with Panda Express. The food was about the same for a third of the price.

Stopped in Noodle Asia right before the Blue Man Group show inside The Venetian. What a bargain compares to other restaurants available inside various resorts in Vegas. 

Authentic chinese/asian food with an extensive menu, including pan fried noodle. soup noodle, typical rice dishes and even porridge. Price is very reasonable considering the quality, portions and location (Vegas). 
Food is well done with fresh veggies and marinated meat, not salty or greasy (which is the problem with most chinese joints in my opinion). 

Service is quick meaning if there are folks waiting for seats, your check will come rather quickly after you finish eating and before you even walked away from the table, waiter is already cleaning the table for the next customers. 

For the price point, I have no complaint.

Service was awful! We waited fir our check at least 15 minutes after asking for it.....while we watched our waiter amble about as if he had no idea how a restaurant works. Food was ok. Not worth the wait. That was our first experience.  As this restaurant is right across from the Venetian poker room, we ended up back there 2 more times during our trip...and sat at the counter, not a table, which fixed the service problem.  Also, the soup and dim sum selections are MUCH better than the pan fried noodle dishes (those served like lo mein in a regular Chinese restaurant). So if you stick with soup and dim sum and sit at the counter, you'll be just fine.

can't take the asian out of me. i duno about you but when i'm drunk or hungover i need me some asian cuisine, even if it's mediocre. 

what i ate:
- combo fried rice: unremarkable. as expected. a bit on the oilier side. enough for two people. 
- egg flower soup (cup): exactly as expected. unremarkable

pros:
- asian food, something for everyone. while leaned more towards chinese cuisine, there was pho, dim sum, etc. 
- open 24/7
- located on campus at the hotel i was staying at
- fast efficient service. traditional asian style as in, flag down your server if you need something. 
- fresh coconut water/juice. when you're hungover, this is a godsend. 

mediocre:
- the food was so so. i mean it wasnt bad, but it wasnt great either. 

cons: 
- price was a bit steep for the food, but you're paying for the convenience of not having to drive to chinatown. 

would i come again? sure why not?

I stopped by Noodle Asia for an emergency soup break. It was cold and snowy outside and I was fighting a cold as well so the fact that I was at the Venetian helped me decide on eating there.

I ordered the Mushroom Chicken Noodle Soup ($13.95).  Oddly enough, no mushrooms were to be found (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_j2EtQtgLuXGRBfbM5YwZA?select=T0-NanAljdtgnKdr4rwP7g).  There really wasn't much to brag about this soup.  The chicken was boneless and and the broth was a little on the bland side.  But I'm just glad that it did it's job in keeping my body hot when it was 32 degrees and snowing outside.

There's nothing really bad to say about this place though.  It's conveniently located in the middle of the Strip and the prices slightly inflated, but if you're in need of some hot noodle soup, especially during the cold winter, this is a great spot.

When we were here working CES back in January, we asked our associates from China where they'd been eating while they were here: 

"Noodle Asia." 
"Really? Chinese food? Didn't want to try anything else?" 
"Noodle Asia's good."

That about sums it up. It's the only Chinese I've had on the Strip that actually caters to Asians and doesn't orange chicken-up or gourmet bland-out the food. In 626 it might have to work a little harder, but in Vegas it hits the spot when you want a Chinese restaurant meal. Both noodle dishes were excellent, the Buddha Feast (veggie) Pan-Toasted and the Combo Stir-Fried Soft. BBQ Pork was tender, spring rolls crisp, fried rice clean.
My favorite place for hot schezwan soup.  $18 is a lot to pay for a bowl of soup but this is worth it.
The food here was OK, nothing special. I dont think I would go here again unless I was stuck at this casino and had to eat really late again.

Dumplings were ok, not the best I have had
Vegetable fried rice had tomatoes in it and didn't taste good had to add hot sauce to eat my food, and let's not talk about the shrimp in lobster sauce.
And the service wasn't great

This is one of my favorite restaurants in Las Vegas. Food is always good , service is fantastic and the waitress will always come and check on you no matter how busy they are. Throughout my dinner tonight i was asked 3 times. :) 

The portion is huge too. Don't be afraid of the price. It's not like that one restaurant in Mandalay Bay.

If you crave for Asian food, this is the place to be!
Everytime I have come to Vegas, I always eat here. Their food is fast and good! I'm Chinese so I know! Just a little overpriced considering it's Chinese food.

Happen to be at the Venetian and in need of a late night snack or dinner?? This is the place for you! Opens till 3am which is definitely a plus.

The menu features large portions of your usual Chinese noodle dishes, rice plates, rice porridge, and soups. We ordered a large hot and sour soup and a BBQ Pork and Roasted Duck rice place to share. After ordering, our meal came out in less than 2 minutes. It's really that fast, no joke. The soup was very tasty and flavorful - perfect blend of the hot and sourness. BBQ pork and roasted duck were delicious as well. Our late night cravings were definitely satisfied here.

Very expensive but very good Chinese food. The service is fast and friendly. The food is cooked immediately and is out in minutes. On a slow day, you can see the chefs watching you eat just to make sure they didnt screw it up. If you're willing to spend the extra dough, then go here. The lines can get long though, but they move people in and out rather quick.
Had the Szechuan beef noodles. Beef was delicious, but noodles could be softer, tasted a bit raw at first.

This place is horrible. Food is bland and oily. It's the worst "Chinese" food I've ever had. Combine crap food with a $60 price for 2 (no alcohol), and you get a very angry eater!

Their XO shrimp was like eating store bought noodles covered in oil. It had no taste and 4 shrimp.

The noodles in broth had no taste at all. Noodles and water.

The worst were the  pot stickers. They were big fat doughy fried crap that were an insult to Chinese chefs around the world.

Avoid this tourist trap at all costs! I guarantee you the 4 star reviews are posted by employees and their friends.

Surprisingly delicious for what it is. I didn't expect much, but happened to be in the Venetian and jonesing for some noodles. Fair prices for Vegas, great food. Ok service. Only knocked off a star because they charge $6 for Thai Iced Tea, which costs almost nothing to make, and then would not offer refills, which is standard in most Thai places. For that price, I expect a refill. Overall though, no complaints about anything else, and I would visit again. The pot stickers were amazing.
Very tasty. Clean and fast. I ate too much. Only cause I had half of my wife's dinner.  Pot stickers are a very good starter.

I'm slowly arriving at the conclusion that the Venetian has no good places to eat (note - at the time of this posting I still had not eaten at Bouchon). 

With regards to Noodle Asia - Maybe I'm jaded by living in SF where you get great dim sum (Hung Tu Seafood restaurant is my favorite dim sum joint in the bay area if anyone cares) and chinese food in general. This place was nothing to write home about. Standard fare that you can get in any run down Chinese take out place in the U.S. 

Don't think i need to waste my time on this place anymore.

Meh.....just meh.

Good sized portions, but average tasting. Chicken lettuce ($13) wraps were pretty yummy. Black peppered beef udon ($15), wok tossed, had a strange taste so had to send it back. Mongolian beef ($16) I would not order again. 

Service was somewhat slow, had to ask one waiter who had to ask another waiter to get our waiter when we needed something. Had to ask for refills. Had to ask for bill. 

If your hungry and dont have high expectations this is your place.
This place was amazing!! I got the combination rice it was sooooo good. We really enjoyed ourselves

Spicy beef noodle soup!!!

They serve dim sum, but we came solely for the soup after a long night of fist pumping. Service isn't too warm and friendly, but they're prompt. The beef noodle soup comes out piping hot, and the broth has just the perfect amount of spice. The chunks of beef are soft and exude flavor, and the noodles are great. LOVED it!! It's also perfect for hangovers... just saying. Definitely want to make this one of our stops on our many Vegas excursions.
We had a great meal here. Beef W/ Broccoli and pork fried rice. Great service and a pleasing place for a meal

Walked in after traveling on a plane. It was late and we checked into our room and decided to check out the casino quickly and grab a quick bite to eat. They sat us down at a table, brought us plates. My wife and I tried to get someone's attention no luck. Looked around and waited 10 mins so we were starving and got up and left!  No one even noticed us leaving or stopped us.
I've never done that before but felt after being ignored we had no choice!

We had the noodles with bbq pork and duck and the Shanghai rice cakes.
