I ordered the Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup based on everyone's reviews. They made it seem like it was amazing but it was just... okay. The soup was strong in flavor, but the noodles were ordinary and the meat was tender yet bland.

Overall, it was pretty average. The food was decent, but the wait really ruined it for me.
This restaurant is right in the casino and is very affordable. Service was fine but all the food - meh

This place is delicious! I asked a poker dealer how this place was and he said it was ok? (He wasn't Asian) I gave it a try and it's the real deal! I return to the poker table and a player asked how I liked it and I said it's excellent! He responds this place is crap. I asked what he thought was good Chinese food and he responded pandas didn't talk to him the rest of the night!

We got to Venetian at 1:45AM. Glad Asia Noodle was still open. Had the shrimp pot stickers and Szechuan beef noodles. The rich spicy taste of the soup was perfect for my palate.
Great place to go for a late night food craving!

We went to Noodle Asia after we saw Panda at the Palazzo, so it was pretty late, and we were glad we could find a decent place open late.  We were a large group (16 people), and they were able to seat us quickly (might have been more difficult if it hadn't been so late).  Food was decent, and large amounts.  I had pork and rice congee, and the bowl was huge.  I thought I was going to have breakfast out of it as well, but it was so good, I finished it before I knew it.  Service was good, adaptable, when more of our extended party arrived after the rest of us had already been served.  Pretty expensive, but its on the Venetian casino floor, so what else would you expect?
Sat for 15 minutes without food or water while 4 other parties got their order taken. Service is terrible here. I had to get up and grab the manager before she came over to get our order and drinks.

This is one of the cheapest and most authentic places for Chinese on the Strip.  It's conveniently located and the dishes come out fast.  I had a variety of the soup noodles and the congee.  After tax and tip, it came out to be less than $30 for two dishes.  

I've been here on separate occasions with family b/c my parents prefer to eat Chinese and I've had no complaints.
good late night asian food, nice staff. a little overpriced

The intoxicating smell of Asian food was what drew us straight into this place inside the casino. 

After we ordered our food, most of it came out fast expect the main dish which the waitress forgot and then later brought out after we asked for it. Food was mediocre at best and they have a few gluten free options but not many. 

Most of it was bland and seemed like a to go style Chinese restaurant. About an hour after we left the restaurant, both my husband and I got sick and felt sooo sick to our stomachs. 

What a bummer because we had another dinner to attend and it totally messed up our stomachs for it. 

If you are in a rush and need something quick after a night of being intoxicated then this mood may be appetizing but if you are sober and looking for good Chinese food...this food is not it.

Tried to rush us out, waiter who sat us down never returned to us with an answer to our query. Ordered the seafood noodle dish which was bland, cold in parts (i.e. Squid and prawns). Rice porridge was a nice change to the usual Chinese menu and the next server did ask if we whisper for side plates / bowls so we could share our food which was a nice little touch. Small but varied range of beers (three comes to mind). Overall a very disappointing evening, based on a recommendation of a befriended flight attendant.

As Terry K told me, "don't go looking for Asian food on the Strip, go Spring Mtn", but yep we hard head!  But this place, we really like.  Our usual over order of mix fried rice, beef udon stir fry, Won ton soup, Har gau and spring rolls.  Only the spring rolls were mediocre, but everything else tasted really good.  So yep five star for me for finding good Chinese food in a casino.
Service is terrible. Don't pay with cash they expect the change to be tip. Ordered roast duck and they didn't have it, which I wasn't informed of and still waited 45 minutes for it. F*ck this place

Okay Chinese food nothing special. The good thing is that they are open late, about the only place. Came here twice late at night. First time I had the egg flower soup. We shared the Mongolian beef and rice. Pot of hot oolong tea. Mongolian beef tasted good to me but a bit spicy for my gf. So the next time we had orange chicken. Eggflower soup tasted different the next time, not as tasty.

Service is good.

The beef noodle soup and Black Pepper beef udon are great!  But they lose a star for charging for tea...

Next to the sports book at the Venetian.

Expect to wait for a seat during standard meal times.

Service is spotty when they get busy so you need to get the attention of the waiter.

Best noodles of any Chinese restaurant in Vegas.

The place is nice and the service was good. Keep in mind they werent really busy. I liked the food but you get the feeling something is missing on the flavor. Only tried their noodle dishes, didnt try their soups

This place is a little expensive for what it is. 

The service is a little slow to seat people.  I ordered the Sczechun beef noodles, which was a noodle soup.  It was good but a little spicy.  My bf ordered the seafood comination noodles, which had pan fried noodles.  I thought his dish was great.  Our other friend order beef stew wonton noodle soup which I didn't try but he said it was okay.  We also ordered potstickers, the skin of the potsticker was too thick. This place is a little too expensive for what it is.

This restaurant has a view of all the giant screens of the sports book. The food here is decent and is a nice place to have a little Chinese food after a night of drinking and partying.

I've ordered the Work Won Ton Soup, and I was expecting something fancy. It's just regular Won Ton Soup with some Char Siu, Chicken, and Shrimp thrown into the soup. Nothing special for a $20 bowl of dumplings! Where I'm from, a bowl like that would cost $5. 

I would still come back to this restaurant even though the food isn't the best. I like the view of all the sports channels and I usually stay at the Venetian during my stays. 

Don't come here expecting anything particular, and enjoy the hot food with a stunning view.
This place is awesome. Very much impressed. It's funny I was the only Non asian person in there lol

BBQ pork & duck noodle soup was just okay. The broth was a bit salty and they were skimpy on the meat. The Szechuan beef noodle soup wasn't any better. The broth had too much of a soy sauce taste and there were barely any vegetables.

THE place to be after drinking and walking all over the strip!  Tucked away next to the casino floor and the Venetian sports book, this was not an obvious choice unless you were already in the Venetian.

My wife and I shared the chicken lo mein which was quite delicious, but strangely included red and green peppers.  I was on cloud 9 once I added the garlic pepper paste to crank it up to 10.  We added in the bbq roast pork which was dry, but the sauce made up for it.  We also had the obligatory "crab" rangoon, which was suprisingly good.  So often rangoon can be stale and chewy...not so at Noodle Asia.

Based solely on food I would give this place 3 stars, but since it satisfied an incredible craving for me, I bumped it up a notch!

It's slightly too expensive for what you're getting.  Also, I didn't really like the flavor of my noodle dish.

I'm also not sure how the heck this place was categorized as "dim sum."  THIS IS NOT A DIM SUM RESTAURANT.


Edit: I see they changed it from "dim sum" to "chinese".  Good job, Yelp!

Drunken friend: Let's go to Noodle Asia...this place looks hella good!  Next morning sober, same one: Let's go to Noodle Asia.  Buzzed ass not feeling so good me after Tao Beach: Give me 30 minutes to sleep then I'll get ready for our dinner at Scarpetta.  30 minutes go by...Me: Okay, give me 15 more minutes....another 15 minutes and I'm still sleeping...5 minutes before my dinner reservation, okay, I'll call Scarpetta to cancel, let's just go downstairs to Noodle Asia.   

Went downstairs a little after 7 the other Saturday and got a table easily.  I wouldn't say this restaurant is Asian fusion, as it's more "authentic" than the likes of let's say PF Changs and Hakasaan, but like I asked the waiter what type of noodles were the beef rice noodles and he said they were like chow fun.  So I dedcied to go with the beef rice noodle but asked for it gravy style instead of the dry version.  I was surprised that they were actually the thinner rice noodle (not super thin like vermicelli, but Chinese chow fun noodles are thicker than the noodles I got).  While the noodles were slightly thinner and the gravy wasn't 100% like what I get back at Chinese restaurants back home, Noodle Asia serves up some good, comforting Asian food.  The quality of the ingredients were a little better than typical Chinese restaurants as well.  The spicy wontons were a favorite and my chow fun was huge enough to serve up to 3 people, or one really hungry friend plus me (he helped me out in addition to his entree).  My "chow fun" was $15, which, yes you can get half off off the strip, but, first off, if I couldn't even make it to Cosmo, then there was no way I was going to make it off the strip, and 2 it's expected to be pricier as it's on the Strip.  

Service was pretty good, minus a slightly older lady with RBF and major attitude when I asked for change, and for two cards to be charged a certain amount.  3.5 rounded up.
Great food. Awesome location. Service was kind of sub par. I had the mopa tofu and it's the best I've ever had.
Food was delicious. We had pot stickers, crab rangoons, and beef noodles. Service was good but was a long wait for food to be cooked.

I think I come here almost every time im in vegas for some reason or another. It IS the cure for any hangover and I always want some asian goodness and am too lazy to drive that one mile to china town. 

My personal favorites here are the beef noodle soup and fried rice. Extremely oily but just oily enough to soak up the alcohol from the night before. 

For vegas, the prices are reasonable you can probably get away wtih spending 12 bucks an entree and the best part is its walking distance from ti wynn venetian and palazo.

We had a Hotel credit so why not make use of it.  We we're seated fairly quickly and waitress was pretty helpful, but in a rushly mannered. Food wise it was okay. I would reccomnded the noodle dishes over the rice. The wonton dumpling soup had very nice amounts of delicious dumplings, however the broth could use a bit more flavor, same as for the shrimp Fried rice. The bbq pork and roasted duck with rice was good, but needed more meat. Overall for a westerner aspect it is really good, but from an eastener okay and pricy.

Just okay -- certainly nothing to write home about. We went in person to place a carryout order of combo fried rice, combo lo mein and potstickers. If you're expecting a smile from any of their staff, don't hold your breath. Vegas is full of restaurants which means tons of options for customers to choose from -- so, service needs to set you apart. In this case, their unfriendly customer service took their star rating down by two. The reason for losing the third star was the food; the combo lo mein/noodles were prepared with lots of green peppers which is a huge negative given: 1) the menu description made no mention of the entree having green peppers, and 2) our palates despise green peppers. Also, for the price ($16.95 per entree), there should've been much more seafood, chicken and bbq pork. So, pretty much an expensive disappointment all around.

the BEST place to eat after 1 a.m. :) 


if you haven't tried their Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup then try that first (or have at least one person from your group order this dish) 

my second favorite dish: mooshoo chicken/pork. chinese style burritos with hoison sauce

trust me... you won't be disappointed. we stop by everytime we're in vegas... just like the regulars stop by el taurino in L.A. we stop by here in vegas :) hopefully you like it as much as we do.

Pretty decent chinese food for the strip.

It's strip prices for sure, but when you crave crispy Hong Kong style fried seafood noodles this place won't disappoint.  The red oil wontons are a pass, not good.  the beef noodle soup was good as is the beef chow fun.

It'd be great if they were open a little later on the weekends, because coming back from the club at 3am they're already closed.

Pricey! ouch! never paid this much for the same style dishes in SF but here is vegas and it is pricey no matter what restaurants you dine on the strip hotels. I am just glad that their Chinese food is authentic! I have been here couple times over the past few years their level of service and quality of food have been consistent, will keep coming back!

I had high expectations for Noodle Asia because I noticed long lines for this place while watching football games at the adjacent Venetian sportsbook.  Long lines are usually an encouraging sign at a restaurant so we decided to join the crowd. 

If it is available on the menu, then I tend to be a creature of habit by ordering Kung Pao Chicken at practically every Asian restaurant I visit. This restaurant was no different. In a way, it's my barometer for judging Asian cuisine. Unfortunately, I was not impressed with their Kung Pao Chicken at all. The chicken was tough and dry while the sauce was clumpy and somewhat syrupy.  The texture to this sauce reminded me of melted caramel and not the typical thin Kung Pao sauce. The taste was mostly sweet and tangy rather than spicy. A strange taste for a Kung Pao dish.  It just was not enjoyable.  On the other hand, the shrimp stir fried noodles, potstickers, and won ton soup were great. My wife and I were really pleased with all these noodle dishes and how they were cooked, steamed and fried to perfection. All the vegetables, seafood and meat in these dishes were fresh and delicious. The cabernet sauvignon was a perfect complement to wash down all these dishes. 

The service here was excellent.  We were constantly checked on and asked if we needed anything. I would also like to thank the hostess for seating my wife and I at a table that faced the sportsbook so I could continue to watch the football games without any interruption while enjoying our meal. 

I am giving Noodle Asia three stars because they failed my Kung Pao Chicken test but excelled with the noodle dishes and service.

Food was below eating standards. The chicken and the beef were like chewing on rubber bands. the beef did not appear to be cooked all the way through 

The service was rushed and not personal at all of our food was brought out at separate times 

I would not recommend this place at all unless you like being dissatisfied wasting money and unsure if your going to end up sick later in the day on your vacation

I was really craving noodles and this was very close as we were staying in the Venetian hotel and had passed by this place multiple times while walking through the casino. 

The service was very fast, and they brought out the food very quickly. I ordered the Pai Goo Noodles. The portion was very large and the broth was very filling. Wasn't the biggest fan of the pork, but it was very crunchy. The noodles were on the gummy side, but it definitely satisfied my craving for noodles.
The food is decent but over priced for what it is in my opinion. We enjoy this place for late night food because who doesn't love greasy Chinese food at 2am!

Grabbed some food to go and ate in the sports betting area next door. The pork congee was good though it could've used more meat and my shrimp wonton mein (yellow noodles) was exactly what I needed and wanted. 

They get pretty busy both in house and take out so come early. 

You can also purchase their beer to go, which may be cheaper than the bar.

Terrible. The server never asked how we were doing he just walked up and said are you ready? we ordered Mongolian beef orange chicken shrimp dumplings and won ton soup everything was terrible except for the fried rice, which we also asked if we could upgrade to and pay extra for and The server responded no we have a side you can pay for? Isn't that The same thing and don't you want to say yes to guests?  The server was rude and transactional as could be . The  wife and I both work for casinos on the strip and both agreed that if we acted this way there would be repercussions. This was my birthday dinner (and we only resorted to this spot because Yardbird was closed for a private event) but the server never cared to ask..

Such good noodle soup and dim sum! I asked the waitress for a recommendation and when I said "spicy" she recommended the schezwan beef noodle soup which was amazing!  The pot stickers and spring rolls were also very good.  Definitely will return!

If your a noodle liver then this place is for you.  Definitely hands down delicious Noodle soups.  Good luck with picking which noodle to order.  Big portion size and flavor of the soups are delicious. Service is great.  The female manager is really awesome.  She has great customer service that makes you want to come back.  You feel at home in this bustling Restaurant.  They get really busy.

Classic authentic Chinese noodle restaurant. Ordered the XO hand made noodles with pork and vegetables. The noodles were soft and seared with a spicy garlic oyster sauce style and was great. Will order again. The menu is straight forward with a selection of 20-25 different entries. Service was decent but the value for food versus the size of the food portion could of been better. A bit pricy for Chinese food.

We ate here on Sunday night around 2am.  Perfect timing, as they are open til 3am.
We partied at XS @ Encore and walked back towards the Venetian just to have some chinese grub, instead of taking the taxi to chinatown back/forth for the same amount of dough.

Had the porridge dish as well as the fried chicken wings & also the szechwan beef noodle soup and singapore fried noodle.   Sounds like alot of food for the 3 of us, but it was actually pretty good to cure the buzz and the quality wasn't bad for casino chinese food.

Only gripe was, the porridge was lukewarm and they promptly took it back and heated it up nicely for us.

Worth a shot if you just want some quick chinese food and are near the Venetian.

Woohoo! As good as it gets!
I had eaten here 3 yrs ago while on a Company trip and this time took the wifey here and once again had an amazing meal wifey ordered the Panfried noodles and Shrimp and I ordered the Chinese Sausage fried rice and they were both absolutely amazing and tasted just deeeelish.
I have always loved the concept of the open kitchen and just loved this place.
We will most definitely be back as the sign of a great Chinese joint is when you look around and see everyone of the same ethnic background there!

Tip:  If you're a small party and do not want to wait for a table, go straight to the bar and grab a seat.  No wait with instant service.

My Review:

I ordered the Schezuan Beef Noodles, and damn that sh*t was a bowl full of deliciousness.  If you're in the mood  for noodles but not wanting pho, I highly recommend coming here and ordering this dish.  

Noodles were definitely fresh, the broth had a nice kick to it, and the chucks of beef with tendons still attached made my day.  Perfect for a hangover.  

I wouldn't order the dim sum here though, our shrimp har gow tasted like it was sitting on a warmer/steamer for too long.

My cousin practically lives in Vegas and he highly recommended me to eat the Won Ton Mein here. It's like his go to dish so I made sure to eat here during my trip. I arrived a little after 7pm and the place wasn't very busy. The service was initially attentive and the workers spoke Chinese very politely to me. They gave me the option to get the dimsum the same time as my noodle dishes or as an appetizer. I chose it as an appetizer. This was a nice option to have but I wish I got all the food the same time because it got busy and it took awhile to get my noodle dishes. Service also wasn't that great toward the end of my meal so this place is more a 3.5 spot. 

It's not often I come to Vegas anymore so I ordered up a feast. I got their Har Gow, Hong Kong Won Ton (Mein), Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup and some hot tea. Hot tea is not free!! I'm Chinese so paying for hot tea at a Chinese restaurant is foreign to me. 

Food:

The Har Gow was very good and went great with their chili oil (you need to ask for this item, it's not on the table as a condiment). Har Gow was large and was easy to pick up without it falling apart. The shrimp was fresh and sweet. 

Hong Kong Won Ton was just as my cousin described. It's really good and the won tons actually had meat inside vs just fat and filler. Soup was like Hong Kong broth and there was just the right amount of noodles. (Add the chili oil if you like spice, it was sooooo good!)

The Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup was good but my least favorite. It was the dish that I left unfinished. The broth had good flavor and had a slight kick to it. Noodles and beef were ok but nice option for noodles here. Portions were generous but broth could have been hotter (temperature wise).

This is my go-to when I'm staying at the Venetian (which is most of my trips to Vegas). My boyfriend and I love this place for their beef noodle soup and have brought our friends with us. What we've learned is that Noodle Asia is only good for their beef noodle soup. Anyone who has ordered anything else got meals that were average or less than average. So now we make sure that those who go there only order their beef noodle soup. Don't try to get fancy or anything. Beef noodle soup or bust. It is pricey because you're on the strip, so go to Chinatown down the street if you want something cheap.

5 stars.

I know...ironic isn't it? How could a noodle restaurant in Las Vegas be this good? Well, ask yourself this: would a noodle restaurant located in the Venetian be able to survive if it WASN'T this good?

I keep coming back for the schezwan noodle soup (niu ro mein). The soup is so wonderfully rich and complex with just a hint of spiceness. It's so deliciously satisfying and soothing! The noodles have just the right amount of bite. I wish the meat was just a little bit more tender, but still very good nonetheless. 

I still don't understand why they niu ro mein is so much better here than at any place I've had in Alhambra/Monterey Park. Shrugs...oh well. Just try it for yourself and swing by the Bouchon bakery afterwards for dessert.

Noodle Asia is our little gem to go to at the Venetian Hotel.  Located at the casino level between the Dorsey and the Sports Book.  

It is a small place but with great flavor.  We have dined here several times especially for their delicious congee soup (rice porridge).  It's 1am in the morning and your craving Chinese food?  Well Noodle Asia is open till 3am.  A wee bit pricey but worth every penny.  

After eating at Noodle Asia we always win several hundred.  It has happened twice in a row but can not guarantee for others:)

Highly recommend:
Fish, seafood, beef and my favorite....fried scallop congee

Fiery fried chicken wings...has a little kick

Wrinkled Saut√©ed String Beans with sweet basil

Service is great, the cooks are loud and happy feels like we're in  China. 

Next time we are around I will definitely try the Abalone Congee.


Their congee is low sodium for those who are health conscious.  I personally love it sinceit pairs well with all the other orders.

5 star for food and service our waitress was great.
My sister got carryout here late one night. Food was decent, but overpriced!

Food was horrible.  Stay away!!!

Chicken was like rubber.

Service was bad too.

Can believe the Venetian allow them to serve such bad quality food.
Huge let down.

One thing I Miss about LA is Chinatown and the places that serve fresh noodles. Noodle Asia is a little more upscale but it's got great selection. It's located at the Venetian. But not at the best location. Right next to the Race and Sports book, they got one of them there Chinese places. Actually this restaurant houses some of the best fresh noodle makers here. So I'm here enough times when my family comes into town.
Won Ton soup. Large steaming bowl of freshly made won tons. And they're BIG!
Red Won Tons.... Spicy...Not for white people
Large cantonese BBQ plate Yea I LOVE DUCK --- bbq pork is fresh and doesn't look like it's been sitting. Soy sauce chicken...well it's hard to really f*ck up soy sauce chicken.
Pot stickers are fresh! The Sui Mai and Har Gow are fresh.....popping flavors.
Night Market Fried Rice --- YUMMY!
XO Shrimp Lai Fen --- SPICY and Yummy! 
Well watch out --- if you don't like thick noodles --- make sure you watch what you get. Ask the server. 
But overall --- service is efficient and there are actually asian people working and not mexican in the kitchen....

This restaurant had terrible service.  There were 4of us and the entrees came out one a a time.  By the time the last person got their food the first person was through eating.  First entree came out before we finished our soup.  Lazy waitress could refill our water.  Not impressed and the food was horrible.

shiu mai was terrible, not hot & lacked any flavor.  Spicy chicken wings were not spicy at all. Servers were unattentive & literally running around like chickens with their heads cut off. I would not recommend. Much better restaurant  (& prices) elsewhere.
Chicken porridge congee was okay. Kind of bland. Great to eat if you're not feeling well. I probably would not return.
Dan Dan Noodles were horrible and Shanghai Noodles were mediocre at best.  Both dishes had very little meat.  Pass on this place.

Ate here a couple times during a long stay in Vegas.  

It can be pretty pricey, esp for noodles, because you can typically get Pho for less than $10 at any normal restaurant...whether or not it is "Prime" pho.  The pho here is $16.95, but just remember, you're eating at the Venetian, so you can't expect dirt-cheap prices for anything...this is how they roll, so you can either roll with it, or roll yourself out to another eating establishment =p  The pho was very good tho, bigger than I expected, and the broth was pretty good.  

The wonton soup and fried rice were pretty good also, and so was this spicy noodle dish, which I forget at the moment exactly what it was called.  

Lines can be long, even late at night, but because you're in Vegas, you just gotta gamble and go when you're stomach wants you to go and see what happens.

Would definitely eat here again, esp if I'm staying in the hotel, just because it's so convenient.  I DID, however, have one encounter with beverage;  how do you run out of drinks? Granted, we got here after 10, but goodness, no Thai iced tea, chrysanthemum tea, OR Pepsi?! Come on!  Gotta stay stocked...people.  That's the only reason for the 3 star rating...if I come 3 more times and they have the drink I want, then I'll bump them back up.

Pretty good Chinese place for Vegas. We wanted to get an inexpensive but good meal and decided to give this place a try. It's located right in the middle of the casino, which was interesting. Saw lots of Asian patrons so that made me feel better! Haha

Food comes out super fast.  Ordered the curry noodles with bbq pork and shrimp, it was DELICIOUS! Portion size was good for $13 bucks. Also ordered a glass of chardonnay for $7. My friend got a beer and the crispy pan fried noodles.  Overall a great place for a quick bite that won't break your wallet.

I was so pleasantly surprised by this place. I went to Vegas with a few friends and one of them really wanted to go here. I saw the name of the place and thought to myself... really? Noodle Asia?

Good thing I gave it a shot. My boyfriends and I weren't super hungry so we ordered an order of egg rolls and we split a BBQ Pork and Roast Duck noodle soup. Honestly I wasn't expecting much, but this place was pretty good. The broth was toned down for the American clientele, but it was still flavorful and rich. The BBQ Pork and the Roast Duck were so yummy. The egg rolls were just okay, nothing out of the ordinary.

I will definitely be eating here again. I mean, you know the place is good when you go to an Asian restaurant and all you see are Asians eating there.

Delish, authentic, and hits the spot. Pricey for this type of food, but come on, we are in Vegas and at the Venetian. This place would be the bomb for a late night meal after drinking, I'd imagine. I've had the noodle soup, porridge, potstickers...ask for the chili oil to drizzle over your food, this one is super flavorful and good. A gem on The Strip!

Still really liked the flavor to my Szechuan beef noodle soup with it's hint of spice. My boyfriends pho on the otherhand tasted a bit off but I couldn't pick out what it was. My noodles were different from the first time I had it. I had flat rice noodles last time and this time they were regular noodles. Will definitely be back when I'm back in Vegas :) pretty tasty Asian food for an Americanized area.

I think the prices have gone up and the quality has gone down since I was last here (last summer). I think it's pretty middle of the road now. It's decent Chinese food with Vegas pricing. It was previously good Chinese food with subVegas pricing. 

Then again, we split a dish of beef flat rice noodles, some siu mai and drinks and it only cost $34 bucks so I guess that's not bad in the grand scheme of things.  It just didn't taste as good as we remember :(

Good food but had to ask for Mushrooms on my Chicken & Vegetable Noodles. Only came with green and red peppers...no carrots, broccoli, or anything...The Hot and Sour soup is some of the best I've had! The noodles were cooked perfect. I would recommend this place out of all the restaurants in the Venetian...good value

There are quite a variety of reviews for this place, but our experience was quite good. We went with a guy who's been here a few times so we took his lead. Two of us had Szechwan Beef Noodles and two of us had Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodle. The food went beyond my expectations, everything being freshly prepared...the noodles had some zip. The open kitchen reinforced that freshly prepared concept.

It IS on the pricier side (i.e., compared to chinatown), but for us it was perfect. A quick, clean, hearty, not-too-greasy, late-night meal before heading out.

I'll be back.

The WORST Hot & Sour Soup we've tasted, no other taste but Sour. We had to add a lot of soy sauce & hot sauce.
The Shio Mai was good though. The Chicken Lettuce Wrap was ok.
The food is expensive. Not worth it.

I can't believe I  paid $13 for a bowl of beef noodle soup!! But alas, I only have myself to blame. After us ladies got tired of the crowd at Tao, we were pretty famished! This place is inside The Venetian so it was right there. Just as we were seated the waiter rushed us to order because the kitchen was closing. I can't believe how rude he was! He even snatched the menu from my friends' hand as she was still ordering. Unbelievable!!

Our food was just average, nothing mind blowing to me. I was a little tipsy but the waiter killed my buzz so there was nothing fooling me. The expensive food, I can let slide, but the horrible service we got is just not acceptable!

I have been here a few times and have ordered the wonton noodle soup and the schezuan beef noodle soup.  The food is not bad, but for the price I think there are better alternatives in Chinatown.  Service is OK and the ambiance is more like a cafeteria feel.  A good place for a fast lunch, but not a nice place to dine with friends or for a special occasion.

Super expensive for the quality and bland. Although, the portions are decent. Do not come here if you're a vegetarian. There are very few options. I got the veggie fried rice and asked if I could swap in brown rice for the white. The answer was no. I added tofu for some protein ($4 extra). The tofu was fried, but soggy and semi cold. The food came out right away, so clearly it was premade. My fried rice was over $18 before tip! Our waiter was hard to understand and not very friendly. I would choose another place to eat next time around.

Visited this restaurant over thanksgiving weekend. The food was ok. Their noodle dishes and beef were pretty delicious, but I wouldn't recommend their seafood dishes. The soup was not the greatest. The servers over that weekend may have been a bit overwhelmed by the crush of people but ours was particularly mean. When we asked her what vegetarian options were available her answer initially was we have none and then she paused and said these two dishes are. Then my friend asked would it be possible to get these dishes just without the meat. Her response it will be the same price.... Thoughts that doesn't answer his question. He was polite and said that's ok. I just want it without the neat. Her response ok ok but still same price... Ok lady we get it. This all did not make a good impression on us. I would not recommend this place to anyone, however their iced coffee is delicious. If you like that sort of thing grab one to go while you explore the casino floor.

I remembered eating here a few years ago and liked it enough to go back tonight.  When we arrived during the dinner hour, there was a line with Asians, which was a good sign.

Feeling a little under the weather. I was looking for something simple like congee to settle my stomach.  We ordered the congee with dried scallops, a small order of soy sauce chicken, spicy won tons, and a boba milk tea.  The congee was ok, but not much flavor from the dried scallops.  The chicken was served cold and paired well with the congee .  The spicy won tons were good.  

Service was a notch above what you'd expect from a Chinese restaurant.  No complaints here, just don't set the bar too high and you won't be disappointed.

I'd go back to try some other dishes.  Prices were higher than we expected, but the food is authentic without having to drive off the strip.

When the Host was surly and unfriendly we should have taken the clue and walked away -fast.
Unfortunately we did not and had one of the worst Asian meals ever.
The waiter was in a hurry and very unhelpful
The endamame was soggy and barely edible
The pineapple fried rice was bland 
The fried vege noodles was poor
the appetizer was the last thing to come
The waiter never refilled our water
The only good thing we had was-no dessert

Just say no to this terrible piece a.....

What a disappointment!
Wow, this place was great! The customer service was A+ the dim sum was great and the price was very reasonable. We will go back today for some congee ..great place

Not bad, it's a small restaurant amongst the casino and race and sports book area in the Venetian casino. They have a bar area and several tables, but overall, it's a small venue. We had to wait about 15 minutes for a table of 5. No biggie, but the number of tables limits the customers from doing what they do best in Vegas...eating.

Unlike some of the other restaurants in a casino area, this one has some great views of the casino floor and the sports book tv's. So you get some entertainment as well.

I got the roast pork and roast duck with rice combination. For a Chinese owned, Chinese cooked, Chinese restaurant, I was a bit disappointed at the roast duck. Not one of the best ones I've had. The roast pork was decent and the white rice...well it's hard to mess up white rice (unless you give me the crusty, burnt up ones that stick to side of the rice cooker) But no...I didn't get the crusty version. It was nice and flaky. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_j2EtQtgLuXGRBfbM5YwZA?select=bX7Hbk4GbIEsYuQGoh4TRw

I'd probably get the fried rice next time. My compatriots in crime got the combination fried rice and they liked it!!!

We went in for quick lunch during expo thinking the wait won't be too long as most dishes were Chinese food. 
Dim-Sum we had order came out right away which was good (but bit pricey for the amount of food came out) but the noodle dishes we had order took another 30 minutes before it came out which I didn't understand why it took so long, especially when the restaurant was nearly half empty. 

I had ordered Singapore mei-fei which was salty and all noodles were broken as it was over-cooked. My co-worker ordered Vietnamese noodle soup which was good but the side condiments which needs to go into the soup came out 5 minutes AFTER the we had started eating. No point of having them at all. Chicken noodle soup was the worst of all. Soup was bland and not very tasteful, noodles were extremely over-cooked that it was mushy. It seem like it was made awhile ago. Co-worker took 3 bites and couldn't eat anymore. Both noodle soups were just warm, not good when you were expecting nice hot soup.

Price was OK considering Vegas and its location but I had so much better food at much lower price. I don't think I'll be coming back here.

Greeting- yes
Price- cheap for Vegas
Vibe- Airport restaurant like /hotel lobby - no vibe
Parking- at Venetian Hotel
Bathrooms- Pass - hotel bathrooms
Service- OK
Food
It's Chinese food. Nothing special. No surprises. Some good noodle dishes

Tucked away in the Venetian casino next to the sports lounge is 'Noodle Asia', what a wonderful name.  So Asian food on the strip, usually sucks right? Well my group was feenin for some noodle soup but not crappy pho so we decide to come here. 

To be perfectly honest this place wasn't even that bad.  I obviously eat asian food on a daily basis and of course not the best, eh you can't really complain given the demographic and the fact that you're in Vegas. 


Order the Schezuan noodles, i believe it was the first one under the noodle soup section.  Yes it is $14.00 but don't bitch, its by far the best noodle soup dish, dark broth think oily star anise, tender chunks of beef, some not so much as the others. My friends ordered other noodle soups and mine was by far the best, with the most complex savory tasting broth, scoop in lots of hot sauce, bomb! I just wish the broth was hotter and the meat was more tender, but beggers can't be choosy.  

Schezuan noodles + lemonade (free refills) = $20. But if you don't feel like going to chinatown and you're craving some pretty decent asian noodle soup with actual asian dudes (*gasp) cooking in the open kitchen, then come to Noodle Asia.

It was after 11:30 pm and there weren't many options for my Fried Rice cravings because everyone else was closed on a Thursday night. I was on the strip in the Linq area. I read the reviews and it was 50/50. I ordered the chicken fried rice and have to say that the portion was a good size!  It wasn't bad so I'll say It tasted great!  It satisfied my cravings. I mean nothing to complain about except maybe the price? I'd go back!

Another of my favorite places to eat when in Vegas.

It's frequently packed, but worth the wait.  I've tried a number of different dishes over the years and have never been disappointed.  The fried chicken wings are my favorite.  

Service is fast friendly and efficient so you can finish eating and get back to gambling, shopping or make it to some Vegas show.

Price is very reasonable for the quality of food all  while located in a casino
Sichuan beef noodle in soup is good, must try! Otherwise just average, don't order dim sum, it is disappointed!

eh its okay here. 

i like their crab rangoon. and the fried rice was decent but i had to ask for some like sweet sauce to give it flavor. 

pros- fast service

cons- not that much taste to the food, a little overpriced but i guess its vegas.
my friend found a hair in her PHO but they did take it off the bill
one of my shrimp was "properly" cleaned out which is totally gross.

i would just come back for their crab rangoon.

Service is very poor.  We had to chase the waiter down for anything we needed, and on top of it they imposed a tip on themselves? The service was bad and they didn't care because at the end they knew a tip will be imposed.  Last time I checked a tip is earned!

Food was ok but definitely will not come back.  You should definitely not come to eat here unless there is nothing else open or you don't care for bad service.

You should instead go to Pho Kim Lo on Spring Mountain.

Look no further! Your one stop shop for all things with noodles and hot soups are here!

There I was, laying in my las vegas suite thinking I need some hot noodle soup for this slight hangover...Scrolling through restaurants on Yelp went from seconds, to minutes, to almost an hour!

Then my gf had mentioned this awesome noodle house located in the Venitian hotel. 

I was so happy that we had a place to go to fulfill my craving. This place really does the job. 

A few things to try - 

-chinese broccoli 
-roasted duck
-Won ton noodle soup (yellow egg noodles)
-Pho (rice noodles)
-Roasted duck noodle soup (yellow egg noodles)
-Spicy seafood soup (thin udon noodles)

Everything tasted really good. No complaints. The hot soup and broth in my belly satisfied my needs. 

The only issue was that we had to ask 10x for some lemons....

We dined here several times on a recent trip to Vegas simply because we were staying at Palazzo and this is located at Venetian and close by. However, there were definitely certain areas this place excelled at, while others fizzled.

We came one day because one in our party was hungover. We needed jook. This is something they absolutely excel in. The jook is creamy and insanely perfect. Portions are huge too so you might want to share that.

The Cantonese items are all fantastic including "gon chow ngau hor" the beef chow fun, or the soups like the ginger chicken double boiled soup, also fabulous.

But move towards the more northern Chinese selections and things start going south. For instance, the noodles soup with preserved mustard greens and pork -- below average! The noodles were so doughy it made the broth muddy and not clear.

The ma po tofu was dismal -- no flavor and the chile used was incorrect.

One of our friends ordered the moo shu vegetables which she said was delicious -- it looked good, but I didn't try it.

So stick with the Cantonese offerings and stay away from the rest. Service was okay on all of our visits.

AFTER POKER I WAS HUNGRY so I figured I'd try this place. I sat at the bar and made my selection, which was basically noodles with chicken. The plate came quickly and had a big fat shrimp on it.

Being deathly allergic to shrimp I waved my server over and explained. She then, looking annoyed, basically scolded me and said that I should have told her about my allergy before ordering.

Forgive me, but why in the Sam Hill would I mention an allergy when I'm ordering something I'm not allergic to? Are you kidding me?

And is it ever really a good idea to scold a paying customer? Especially on their first time? And now I have to tip on top of it, right?
Had the fish filet congee and beef stew soup.  Everything was below average.  Not horrible just below average.  The beef was the only thing that was good.  Tender and nicely seasoned.

This is a 3.5 star review, but not quite 4.  I had dinner at Noodle Asia on a Friday night around 10:30.  It was busy, but there were a few open tables.  I know from previous experience there can be quite a line for this place, but they usually get through it decently quick.

Our server immediately arrived to take our drink order.  They have the usual suspects for Asian beers as well as a small wine and cocktail list.  I went with Asahi and the server was fairly quick with the refills.  To start we went with the seared shrimp chive dumplings and Har Gow, which are steamed shrimp dumplings.

The appetizers came out fairly quickly, definitely under 10 minutes.  The Har Gow was good but the winner in my estimation was the shrimp chive dumplings.  They have a nice crispy exterior and really strong chive flavor.  If you do not like chives do not order this dish, as it is definitely chive-forward.  I love chives and not surprisingly I loved this dish.

For my entree I had the Pho Special Prime which includes rare ribeye, brisket, tripe, and meatballs.  The broth was good but it lacked the depth of flavor I have had at many pho places.  The brisket and ribeye were good, the trip was not as good but certainly not bad, but the meatballs were a miss for me.  The texture was very hard as if they had been overworked.  I would get the pho again but I would request extra brisket instead of meatballs.  I did have to pull a couple of pieces of meat out of the soup in order to cut them on a plate.  They were too large to eat in one bite.

I would order the dumplings again for sure and would try the pho, provided I can get the meatballs substituted.  This is a more than solid joint if you are at the poker room or sportsbook and need a quick bite.  I will likely return.

This place isn't anything super special. It's expensive because it's inside of the Venetian. 

If you're like me and crave crispy noodles all the time come here for their crispy noodles it was delicious, but it's hard to fail at crispy noodles.

Their side of rice costs literally $2 that's insane ping pang pong is way better and much more affordable and located minutes from here off the strip.

If you do come here avoid the hot and sour soup. It's super sour like they over added something.

shanghai stir-fried noodel was good
long line
others were just okay
service was only 2 stars

I would say they deserved 4 stars but it's on the expensive side when it comes to dishes, but what do you expect since it is located inside a hotel and on the Las Vegas Strip. My family had the Orange chicken, Mongolian Beef, Rice, Egg Soup, Shrimp Dimshum, and Wonton Soup. The rice was perfect! Love when a place knows how to cook their rice, not hard, yet not mushy. The Mongolian beef was my favorite, very soft and tender. But it was $20, my family overall had 7 items and 1 drink and that became $106. But, when she came over to pick up the check she said that it did not include tip, and if we wanted our change back. Now, we were going to give her tip, but she decided to give her even less because that was so rude and made her look money hungry. As well as making the restaurant look bad

located off the casinos, below tao, in the venetian , through the woods...
you will find noodle asia - the noodle house that all your asian friends talk about, and that is how you have validated the quality....

except for this time...
Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup - is , eh disappointing to say, but nothing close to all the hype that it has been built up to. its very salty, the noodles seems as though its been hand made (a lot like korean kal gook soo) yes the beef is tender, the soup is sour / salty.

if you really want it to hit the spot, pack yourself some korean cup onoodles and order in some hot water through room service.

10.16.10

So good when you're hungover and need something close by.

Granted, you can get any of these dishes for half the price off the strip, but for the convenience, I'm ready to shell out the extra dough.

Cantonese beef stew.  Go.

Located in the Vinettian this place opens till 3am.  It's a pretty pricy place for Chinese food but I guess if you'd rather eat anything else than sandwiches or pancakes, this is a good alternative. 

Food:  Decent.  I got the pho and it was a bit too salty for my taste.  They don't have all the Pho condiments I usually throw in to spicy up my soup but again, I'd rather be eating this at $19 bucks than pancakes. 

The Duck was good and the dry noodle dish was also good.  

Over all experience was decent.  Service was decent and being open till 3AM def gets another point.
Absolutely fantastic beef soup....and the sauce for the potstickers....wow!

I used to have dinner here almost every night while staying at the Venetian.  They had a dish on their menu called MINCED BEEF and it was served over rice with an egg on top,  scallions and peas.
I loved this entree, however, they discontinued it and it no longer is on the menu.  I am really disappointed about not being able to order it and wish they would start making it again.  It's a really simple dish and all they need is ground beef to be able to make it specially.  I would definitely give them 5 stars if this would be put back on their menu.
I would really like the recipe so I could make it at home.
Food was great! We ordered shrimp fried rice which was extremely good! Only downfall of the place is the service is slow but if you're in the mood for a moderately priced meal this is the place!

I mean, it's not baaaad. 

My friends and I wanted something hot and soupy to recover after a night out. Since there's not that many Asian food options in The Venetian (we didn't want to venture far), there was a 30-minute wait around noon. 

3-stars because I ordered the Snow Cabbage noodle soup with no pork, and it came out with pork............. I had to scoop off all the snow cabbage since the minced pork was everywhere on top. Basically paid $17 to eat plain noodles. 

Make sure to double check with your waiter when you order!

I've been devirginized from the glory that is Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup.

This meal was everything I had hoped for and more. IT'S THE ISH! After getting a beating from Tao and XS, all I needed was some fresh, chewy noodles, soft, tender chunks of beef, and piping hot, spicy/sweet broth down my throat.

Yes, my friends, it was like a euphoric version of Pho after a bad night of drinking in K-Town. 4 stars, only because I have to give the other items on the menu a taste.

I went here twice during a recent visit to Vegas.  I plan to return.  The first time I had the Shanghai Noodles.  They were very good and overall tasted a lot like home cooking --- nicely sliced cabbage and lots of black mushroom.  Just a little more chicken and maybe a little less oil, and I would call the dish excellent.  The second time, I had the Szechuan Beef Noodles; it usually doesn't come with any vegetables, so I asked for some to be added -- $2 extra.  The noodles had a nice, fresh texture.  The beef was also very good, tasty chunks of some non-steakhouse cut cooked until even the little bits of embedded tendon were tender.  It was moderately spicy, but only maybe a weak New Mexican medium.  Of course, I could have bit into the little red chilis for more heat.  The soup was just okay --- a noticeable soy sauce taste and not enough beef taste.  The dish was good enough to enjoy, but next time I'll try something else on the menu.  For a moderately priced Chinese restaurant at a hotel on the Strip, this place is very good.

I was slightly inebriated, so I THINK this is the restaurant I went to. hahah. I tried confirming on the Venetian website, but that thing has been down for like 2 weeks now.  Oh wait...I checked out the pictures on here and now I know it is the place I went to.  Phew. 

We ordered:

Postickers- good
Wonton Soup- didn't try it but it looked good
Spicy Beef Noodle soup- it was above average, not that spicy though
Beef Chow Fun- pretty tasty

I'm not sure if I would be more particular about it if it wasn't 2:30 in the morning.  I would come back if it was late and that was the only thing open, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

Only had the szechuan beef noodle soup.  I wish I was able to try more but the noodle soup was very very good.  One of the best Spicy beef noodle soups I've had.  

I had a couple large chunks of fat in mine which I scooped out but other than that, great bowl of noodles.  Only downfall is that it was $14 for the bowl.  

This would definitely make for a good hangover meal.

If you're at the Venetian and you need a quick and tasty meal, Noodle Asia is your best bet.

The Venetian/Palazzo is great for fine dining, but it doesn't have a lot of mid range dining options.  Noodle Asia is great for filling your stomach and satisfying your culinary cravings without breaking the bank.

It has a very typical "in casino" atmosphere, just feet from the extended poker room.  You are always reminded of the fact that you are dining in a casino.  The food is good, albeit overpriced.  We paid $8.50 for a dim sum dish that would normally be $4.00.

Whatever.  You're in Vegas and you're on the strip and it's 11pm.  I really like Noodle Asia, but in reality, I only eat there if I'm about to hit the Venetian poker room.  The food is good, but overpriced.  The location is great, but you are sure to hit a mixture of bachelorette parties and locals trying to get a decent bit to eat.

I really like this place for food. The wait staff are usually unfriendly but they do bring the delicious soup.   The dumplings rate up there with the best. My go to here is the BBQ pork & duck soup. It's rich and steaming and you won't find any better on the strip. After a long day this is the perfect stop before heading to the room.

Had the Kung Pao beef here the other night and it was pretty darn good. This place usually has a small line and the prices aren't too bad given the location. It is located right next to the Venetian Sports Book which is always a great place to catch a big game.

Now where do I begin? This is the worst restaurant I've been to! If there was just a single positive aspect to this place, I wouldn't complain as much. Firstly, our server (won't mention name) was VERY rude.  She would not give us enough time to even look at the menu and kept coming back as if she was trying to rush us out.
The food was terrible. Ordered Shrimp Fried Rice and asked them to make it spicy and make sure to add veggies. That came out with no flavor and an additional $4 for "extra" veggies - which would have been just had there been actual extra veggies. Also ordered Kung Pao Chicken, again asked for spicy, and it came in some sticky sweet sauce and tasted absolutely awful. So overall, meal was garbage. Service was garbage. Upon questioning the additional charge, the same server VERY rudely explained to us that it's for the rice. We said we didn't care about the charge, we'll pay it because we wanted to gtfo. 
I do not recommend this place to anyone.

very good.  came out here on business with a colleague.  went for dinner and had fried rice and a beef dish.  very good.  so good we went back for lunch the next day before leaving town.  most awesome fried rice.  the chicken noodle dishes are fantastic also.  very good place and i beleive it was tucked away inside the venetian.  when  you are done with this meal walk to the gellato store in the venetian for an 8.00 cone of heaven.  wow.  good stuff all around.

Came here for breakfast with a group of 5 after a crazy night. We all wanted noodle soup because soup is always comforting and easy on the stomach. Plus, it was conveniently located inside the Venetian.

3 of us had the Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodle. All 3 of us thought it wasn't spicy at all and it was actually kinda bland. I put maybe 5-6 spoonfuls of chili paste in my bowl to add some flavor. On top of that, it was overpriced at $13.95 a bowl.

I've lived in the San Francisco bay area all my life where there are a million Asian restaurants that serve noodle soup. So, that's why I give this place a 2...."Meh. I've experience better." 

If you don't mind traveling off the strip for an authentic, good noodle soup, go to Pho Kim Long on Spring Mountain Road.

Really good food. If u like Peking duck, make sure u order it, in the appetizer category, with a very good volume, one of the best I have had. 
Other foods are a bit pricy, that's why I gave 4stars. But really taste great.

Oh my dear LORD how does such perfect soup exist?!

At 2am, there was a line to get into this noodle house.  And rightfully so!  Situated next to the poker room, it beckoned me..."You know you're starving...and you just won a $600 pot!  You can afford $15 soup..."

I chose Roasted Duck and BBQ Pork Soup.  It was beautiful.  Glistening, fatty duck and lean slices of BBQ pork floating among baby bok choy over thin egg noodles.  Clean, clear, deep-colored broth...not the oily kind commonly found in your average Chinese restaurant.

I enjoyed every slurp, every morsel.  It will now become my post-poker ritual at the Venetian from now on.  Absolute perfection.

good and interesting chinese food in the venetian. the restaurant is in the middle of the casino floor, so there isn't much in the way of ambiance or privacy. the service is a little slow - our food came out well before our drinks. 

we had potstickers, fried rice, and a spicy noodle soup for lunch. all of them were tasty, and that spicy soup definitely cleared my sinuses. i thought it was a good sign that there so many asian people eating in the restaurant.

we try to visit new restaurants every time we go to vegas, but i might be back to noodle asia for more.

Dim sum at midnight?

Totally normal here... and awesome.

Ordered Har gow, chicken noodle dish, fishball curry and soup.


Food is all great here. Skip the milk tea though.

Worst food I have had. Do not go. Service was bad. Long wait for food.  Rice was mediocre. Chicken not flavorful.  It tasted like the frozen general tsao chicken you buy frozen at the store.  Spring roll appetizer was ok.  Also very expensive being vegas.  For the same price I could have taken a taxi to and from lotus of Siam which is the best Asian restaurant Ever and had a full meal.  If you don't want to leave the casino just go to the burger place in the mall. Much better

this place definitely has the best asian food in all of vegas! and what better way to top off your night after clubbing at tao then to have some noodles at noodle asia??

i've been here about 4 times, couple times drunk and tired after clubbing, and another couple times the morning after...hungover and looking for a hot brothy soup to wake me up.

the Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup is my favorite. the broth is flavorful and kinda tangy.. and the fried rice here is good too. the beef rice noodles are a good choice too if your not really in the mood to drink soup.

obviously this isnt gonna be the best noodle house out there, but its pretty dang good considering its in a vegas hotel, on the strip, in the middle of nowhere, in nevada.

Omg!!! I'm so amazed that this place isn't crazy busy with a line out the door. It tasted authentic as *uck!

Four words: Szechuan spicy beef noodle. 

That is all. 

Your welcome. 

Do it!!!!!!!

I think the MSG has f*#ked with my head.  Six visits.  Why?

Being Asian, I'm insulted that the Venetian would attempt to placate me with this mediocre excuse for a Chinese restaurant sandwiched between the poker tourney area, sports book, and restroom hall.

KISS (Keep It Simple Stupid) review:

Fried rice:  extremely oily and packed with MSG.
Dim sum: nothing special except the price.  3x what you would pay in your local Chinatown.
Noodle soups: correctly made, loaded with MSG, very little toppings, expensive.
Wok tossed noodles: should be tossed out.  Extremely oily and salty from the MSG.

To add further insult, they charge you for every day quality tea.

We all know, too much oil = restroom.  Too much MSG = lots of water = restroom.  Not a smart way for a casino to do business.  But what do I know, I'm still in my MSG coma.

the food here is decent, but as most people said, more expensive than it should be. 

i ordered the si jiu beef wok tossed noodle stuff and it was bland...i had to add spoonfuls of soy sauce, and i wasn't the only one that thought so..everyone at my table that tried it said it was bland too. to me, it was just like the chow mein from panda express, but with beef. sad. and it cost about $14 for that. 

my bf ordered the cantonese beef stew i believe, and that was kind of flavorless too...tasted like ramen i could make from a bag....

two of my friends ordered the bbq duck stuff though and they said it was heavenly. i didn't try it because i don't like duck :( 

maybe we just ordered the wrong things. as for the prices, people are saying you're in vegas so expect to pay that much...and that is true...but i say, if you're in vegas, don't look for asian food and expect it to be good...and no matter where you go, you're going to pay a not so cheap price, but if you're going to do that, at least do it at a place that is not something you can find cheaper and better tasting in chinatown. explore different places that aren't offered around where you are from --- those are the places worth shelling the money out for :D

Came here because I saw on the menu they had some dishes with some Chinese BBQ deli and I was like oh yeah!

There really was not a whole lot of people when I came, so got sat down at a table right away.  The ladies that worked there were very nice.  I decided on getting the bbq pork and roast duck over rice which sticker shocked me at $15.  OUCH!  The food came in 3 minutes.  I am not even joking with you, it literally came out in 3 minutes.  I sent a text out, and the food was there.  Also ordered a Vietnamese Iced coffee.

The food was not impressive.  The roast duck pieces had nothing but skin on them.  Absolutely no meat.  Maybe they saw that I was an Asian guy and they felt that I had enough roast duck in my lifetime and know how it taste like so they are saving it for those that might not have tried it before.  COMPLETELY understand (not really)!  The bbq pork was BRIGHT pinkish/red which almost blinded me.  I think they glazed it intensely, which actually was not too bad.  The rice was eh...rice.  The coffee was not as strong as I'm accustomed to, but was pretty good.

All and all, not worth the 23 dollars total.  Maybe if you look like you've got money, they'll give you the duck with the meat on it though.  Good luck.

The staff were friendly and our service was great.  Food is not so bad but it's not great. I don't know if they purposely under season their dishes because I noticed almost everone around us including myself had to add soy sauce. I also think some of their dishes like the Pho for example is over priced.

My husband and I enjoy eating at Noodle Asia.  

One of our favorites we like to order is their pan friend dumplings.  They are huge!  They are filled with pork and vegies.

Their noodle soup, the duck and bbq pork is delicious as well.  I've tried Mama Woo's Spicy noodles soup too and it was great!

I was not expecting to find an Asian restaurant at the Venetian! I was pleasantly surprised to find this restaurant that didn't require a long wait (seated immediately in fact!), authentic food with Mandarin Chinese speaking servers. We were on a tight schedule so this was a good choice for us. I ordered a bowl of wonton noodle soup. It was filling and the broth was light and refreshing.

This place was really fantastic. First off we needed a place to grab a snack before dinner. We both enjoyed a very large and generous pot of jasmine tea. Next we enjoyed pot stickers and crab ragoons. Both were fantastic. Very large portions and more than we needed. We took some of it back to the room. The service was great and we watched the football game while enjoying our food. Will be back!

We frequent this restaurant every time we could me to Vegas located in the Venetian Hotel. I always get the mushoo pork when I come here it's my favorite. This time they had changed the menu, aww no more mushoo pork! We order a chicken fried noodles and a Mongolian beef mild. The Mongolian beef was awesome and very tasty, noodles I wouldn't order again. This place is kind of pricey for Chinese food at about $20 something a dish for my daughter and I dined and our bill was $56.

Ying Yang fried rice (vegetarian style) was okay. Hit the carby spot, needed a lot of hot sauce. Service was fast and friendly.

Recommend for a bite before going out since it will help before you drink.

Noodle Asian is just great. It's convenient if you're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo. It's not terribly over-priced. And it is literally the best hangover food you can get. I love the spicy red oil wontons, all of their noodle dishes and the duck over rice. Can't speak to how it tastes when you're not drunk/hungover, but it's definitely a must have every time I'm in Vegas!

Im always a bit skeptical about ridiculously high priced chinese food that is in a place that probably caters to mostly non-chinese people.  
However, the food here was pretty good.  I usually would give it three stars for being good but overpriced, but thinking about it, I realized that it should get 4 stars for being overpriced chinese food but still tasty!
Surprise surprise!  
Bad thing is that it didnt have the real chile sauce.   Oh well cant be too greedy.
The other nice thing is that eating there feels like a very clean homey feel of a dingy delicious hole in the wall chinese restaurant but it was in the Venetian. 
Service is slow.

Among the many creative culinary offerings that make the Venetian hotel and casino a stand out on the strip, Noodle Asia isa stand out in its own right. The ultimate round the clock asian restaurant, made to order custom cooked asian dishes are inspiring if not down right energizing.

The noodle selection is awesome, with several dishes featuring flavors from across the continent.

The Singapore vermicelli with curry, shrimp, and pork was spectacular.

Located just outside the poker room, with direct access to the casino floor, the Noodle Asia restaurant is also a perfect stop if you are watching a game in the totally amazing newly redesigned sports book.

I shot a quick photo of the orange chicken we had at 1:15am after a fun evening on the town.

Check them out if you can stop by the Venetian.

It was not bad for chinese food on the strip. I was feeling a little sick from my trip so I ordered the seafood congee and a side of chinese broccoli with oyster sauce. The soup was good and helped with my congested sinus and I felt a lot better after eating. Prices was fair too considering it was inside the venetian hotel.

The morning (or afternoon) after a late night out in Vegas, sometimes a big bowl of soup sounds heavenly.  And since I was staying at the Venetian, this was the closest place to satisfy my craving.

It's located on the casino level near the slot machines.  At around 2pm on a Saturday there was no wait and we were seated quickly.  The restaurant is also next to the sports betting area, so if you're seated in the right spot you can watch the games on the big screens.

I didn't know what kind of soup I wanted, but their Szechwan Beef soup ($14.95) was listed as "Mama Wu's specialty".  It was delicious!  The broth was just the right combination of salty and spicy for me.  The beef was tender and the noodles had a nice chewy texture.  We also had the Chicken Lettuce Wraps ($13.95).  These were good, although on the salty side especially after adding the hoisin sauce.  I wish it had come with more than four leaves of lettuce.   

If you're on the strip and need a Chinese food fix, this is a good option.  Yes, you're going to pay more than you normally would for Chinese food, but what isn't overpriced on the strip?

Love this place !!!  Was staying at the Venetian for business and had nothing but large business meals planned most of the time - but wanted something small, fresh and good.... this place hit the spot.  Had the ramen with which was terrific, also the gyoza - which has a different kind of dough around it, tasted okay, but different - more thick then traditional...  all in all, wish I found this place a few days earlier...

I was pretty intoxicated when I visited this place so the very "openness" of the restaurant didn't bother me. The layout is like that of how you sit in a mall food court. But nonetheless, I had what I'd consider to be probably the best Kung Pao Chicken I've ever had. And the prices are reasonable considering everything cost more in Vegas!
Very tasty food, even when I was drunk. The plate was super hot with freshly made food. It came with large portions of food, mostly veggies & noodles with small pieces of beef.

This place was a definite surprise on how good it was. My boyfriend and I were looking for a bite to tide us over until dinner and holy food did we get enough bites! We both ordered a meal, looking back we could have shared, and both were great. The service was fast and the food came even faster. A must go in between bets in the casino!
Miso Soup, Orange Chicken and Shrimp rolls. Everything tasted great with a doggie bag to spare. Very happy with the service and reasonable Vegas prices.

If you're in The Venetian, Noodle Asia is an a-ok option for some late night sustenance. Yes, it is more expensive than Spring Mountain Road, and yes, as you may have guessed, the menu is noodle-heavy, but there are some solid dishes for snacking. Just ask for what you like without being beholden to the menu options. 

We went in looking for a good garlic stir-fried vegetable without sauce and a spicy, soft noodle. We asked the waitress for just that, and we ended up with a well-executed bok choy and a spicy black bean noodle that wasn't exactly on the menu. The noodle was technically Si Jiu Beef, but it is traditionally a crispy noodle, and we wanted chicken. Our waitress was able to modify the order no problem, so special orders don't upset them! 

I thought both dishes were delicious, especially because they came to the table piping hot. It was a late night, need to sober up snack for us, not dinner, and it hit the spot just right.

The BEST Hot-Sour Soup in the USA, Hands Down !!!! Fast Service. This is a must stop on the strip. Hard to find inside the Venetian. Look for the sports book. Lettuce wraps are fresh and hot. Very Clean Restaurant !!! Try everything on this menu. Jazmin Tea is awesome.....Excellent for late night dining

Tasty Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup - great spice and appreciably on the lighter side compared to more traditional preparations.  Other bowls like the Wonton Noodle Soup and Curry Beef Brisket Noodle Soup were decent.  Across the board, be ready for the Vegas premium that cranks up the cost of everything by $3-5.  Service was fine though be aware that rice dishes can take much longer than the noodle soups (eg. my friend got his plate after everyone else had finished).  That or they just screwed up and forgot the original order.

Possibly the best Chinese comfort food we've found in Las Vegas. While in San Francisco we've scoured the land for great beef noodle soup and have tried our fair share. So to say Noodle Asia stacks up in ranking was surprising to me. The broth is spicy and flavorful with generous chunks of beef. And although portions are big, you still feel like you want more after your first helping. The seating area is nicely lit and provides a warm, comfortable ambiance that helps you recover from the long night out. Sometimes I feel we go to Las Vegas just for this place.

A dear friend recommended this fine dining establishment,
telling me about a certain dish which I shared a nommy sentiment.
The restaurant is Chinese-themed, and it is called Noodle Asia,
a few steps away from the casino floor is where you will find it.

The wait in line was somewhat time-consuming,
so be sure to account for the wait when you are starving.
This restaurant can accommodate parties large and small,
if you are forever alone have a seat at the bar by the kitchen wall.

Their menu has many appetizing offerings,
drinks, foods, and other delicious things.
On the both occasions that I visited with my group,
I got a pot of hot tea, and a bowl of the Sichuan beef noodle soup.

The service here was efficient, accurate, and brisk,
our food order came out in about 10 minutes - nothing was amiss.
The tea was what you'd expect from any ol' Asian joint,
but oh my stars I must emphasize that the noodle soup was ON POINT.

The beef noodle soup had me speechless,
the taste of the broth had the right mix of savory spices,
the meat was exceedingly fatty, with a buttery texture,
and the noodles brought the balance to bring the entire dish together.

All-in-all I'd say Noodle Asia is a must-try spot,
primarily for the Sichuan beef noodle soup fresh from the pot.
Make sure you give this place a whirl,
as you wander about the City of Sin, looking for them hot girls.
lolol.

Love the food here! The soup, noodles, and shrimp is amazing! The only reason why I gave them 4/5 stats is because their service sucks! I kinda expect to get sucky service anytime I'm having Chinese food, so I wasn't too disappointed. I just think the Venetian can hire better trained people to work there. People staying at this hotel expect a certain level of service and the people at noodle Asia don't deliver.
But the food is amazing :) love it!

Good food and spicy (as we like) 
I was interested in more of vegetarian options which and I could get only one or two in the menu but even that was good.

3.5 stars. All I got was a cup of wonton soup because I needed breakfast. It was pretty good and larger than I expected for the price! Service was also very fast, especially since I was just by myself. I was seated very promptly at the bar.

How can I be a hipster foodie when there's a generic Asian casino restaurant that I like? 

It's expectedly pricey, and for me, the rich beef noodle soup with springy noodles hit some familiar chords in one of my favorite comfort foods. 

Not a Vegas expert, but if this was at home in Tennessee, it would really be seriously good eats.

So we came in for a late lunch after a night of hardcore drinking and clubbing. I heard the beef noodle soup was one of the dishes I should try here. The beef was so tender and delicious. The noodles were okay. The soup tasted like there was a lot of msg so of course it was very tasty. I didn't try the other items on the menu. I had the view of all the massive televisions with sports on them so that was a plus. The staff was okay, not too bad.

Every time my bf and I are in Vegas, we stay at the Palazzo so we can eat here. 
Whenever we eat here, I always, always order the spicy ying nan noodles. It's my hangover cure. Besides that, its delicious. It's full of flavor and requires no addition except I like my food spicy so I have to add tons of spice. My bf usually orders the pot stickers and night market fried rice. 
I would eat here everyday during our stay in Vegas if I could but of course, the bf wouldn't allow it. He would always have reservations at 5-star restaurants. But this is my go-to place if I was given the choice.

The restaurant opened late and is in our hotel, so we decided to grab something to eat here before heading up to our room.  I ordered the Beef Black Pepper Udon because it looked really good in the picture on Yelp.  My boyfriend ordered the Mongolian Chicken.  His Mongolian Chicken was pretty good, but I thought my udon noodles was too salty.

Okay now this place is really good!..Fresh ingredients, never crowded and open till 3:00 a.m. I will admit not every dish is unbelievable, bit i've tried many things here and i can only say that the egg drop flower soup or whatever ya call it, was a bit bland, but that kind of soup is bland anyway. And the beef or pork chow fun was a little to greasy for my pallet. other than that, the crispy toasted pan fried noodles with seafood or beef are great. As is the Singapore em fun..Big noodle soups ya can't go wrong like the brisket curry noodle soup...Anyway, when you're on the strip and want some good chinese, stop in the Venetian and check this place out..Oh yea, a bit pricey, but hey, it's in the Venetian...

Ok if you are hungry,  hit and sour soup was bad,  I like the duck n bbq pork noodle,  ph was bad,  special beef noodle was bad as well,  salty, this place doesn't have consistency on their cooking,  one day it taste less,  next day it's salty,  weird,  but the rice was good,  seafoods pan fried noodle was so so, but don't expect the same everyday.  I gave 3  because it's inside the hotel, we eat quickly then went to gamble lol. It's cheaper compare to others restaurants inside palazzo and venetian

Legit Chinese inside a casino in Vegas? What? 

Yes, it does exist. It may be pricier than heading to Chinatown, but its IN the strip so if you are just visiting Vegas its a good option. 

I'm pretty sure someone on management just hired the people from their favorite Chinese restaurant to run this place because the English was sketchy and the food was legit. 

Unfortunately it was a little hard to determine what was actually vegetarian so I just ended up with a very simple noodle dish.. but all my meat eating friends left very happy.

Vegas is not the place for Chinese food. Run away from this place. Want a plate of rice doused in MSG and Kung Pao chicken drowned in vinegar? Come to Noodle Asia! 
The shrimp fried rice is edible and tastes pretty decent. Has an unhealthy amount of MSG in it though. And the Kung Pao chicken is a lie. Just a plate of chicken cooked in vinegar. It even stinks.  
This is just a place for drunk white people. This is not authentic Chinese food. Drunk food for Americans, yes. 
Plus the Kung Pao chicken was $19.95. Shrimp fried rice was $16. 
Might as well hit the strip for a burger or a bag of chips.
Got Chicken fried rice.  Rice itself had good flavor but I can not eat the chicken. Just bland boiled chicken for 15.95. Service is good at 2am. Just wished I ordered something else.
Poor food quality, poor service. Food didn't look fresh. Almost looked like reheated microwave stuff. :(

First time was alright, not memorable but ok. Yesterday I went was bad.  The portions are so tiny for the price they charge.  Do not buy order their wonton noodle.. 15.95$ they couldn't even fill up the bowl. The lamb chop appetizer $15.95 was 2 tiny pieces. Never again.

My family just got to the Venetian and we were very hungry. We ordered some food, but 40mins later our family didn't get our food. People who came 20 minutes after us already left before I even got to eat. My husband argued with the manager and she said that they were out of the food my son ordered. They replaced it with some dry noodles! The food was disgusting and the service, it was horrendous. I will never come here again!

Except for location, this place is really just so so. Tried soup dumpling and char-siu and roasted duck with rice. Just like most HK fast food restaurants, vegetables were not fresh at all.  There are definitely much better choices in Chinatown!

Had the egg drop soup which was pretty standard.

I ordered the Singapore Chow Fun which, to my surprise, was great. It was seasoned well, had good flavor from the wok, and was up to par with an authentic Chinese restaurant (NOT take-out).

Though the prices are a little higher given the restaurant's location, it was definitely a great value considering the amount of food you get.

Service was good, except our waiter didn't speak English very well. We were trying to figure out what on the menu was vegetarian-friendly, but the term "vegetarian" is very loosely interpreted by Chinese people. Should've busted out the Canto!
The worst Asian food i have ever had. Don't spend your money here. Beef was like plastic and seafood was not fresh.

One of my go to spots when in Las Vegas, my friends and I also always make one of our meals here and all dishes are solid.  My personal favorite is the szechuan beef noodle dish.
